speech.para: Let us have a look at how this complex tax manipulation works. In order to qualify for employee shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd one would assume that you must be some type of employee. As Senator Parer said himself, ESP stands for employee share plan and not extra sensory perception. Although, it is obvious that Senator Parer had the powers of ESP as he was able to foresee how much his 44c investment would soon be worth.

What we have here is the moonlighting Senator Parer masquerading as some type of bona fide employee of QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd in order to qualify for the company's very generous employee share plan. In fact, Senator Parer was a director of QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd and the employee share plan was an exclusive club for him and six other directors. How else does a $10 investment entitle them to a $1 million payout on the same day?

Let us not forget that this was just the first of many allocations because as we know Senator Parer has 44 one cent shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd. This still leaves the question of how the $1 million in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd became available to the owners of the 1,000 employee class shares who had invested just $10, of which Senator Parer invested just 12c? This is where the manipulation really comes in.

If we look at the latest ASC return for QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd we see that it has issued a total of 3,683 UNC employer class shares at $1 each but that it has a balance in its share premium account of just on $2.7 million. This means the owners of the 3,683 UNC employer class shares paid a premium for these shares of $2.7 million. This is very significant because it is this $2.7 million that forms the asset base of QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd in which Senator Parer has a $56,300 interest based on his 44c investment in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd.

It is important then to look at the owners of these 3,683 UNC employer class shares. A quick look at the annual return of that company reveals that Advance Queensland Resources and Mining Pty Ltd owns 2,350, QCMM Pty Ltd owns 570 and Tremell Pty Ltd owns 763. As we also know, Advance Queensland Resources is a fully owned subsidiary of QCMM Pty Ltd and that Tremell in turn is 51 per cent owned by QCMM Pty Ltd.

What we see here is a nice little cosy arrangement between Senator Parer and his web of companies that has given life to this nice little tax manipulation. The best part of that is that the $2.7 million sitting in the share premium account of QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd was in fact a tax deduction for all of the companies involved. We know that on that magic day in April 1994 when Senator Parer turned 12c into $12,000 Advance Queensland Resources and Mining Pty Ltd paid QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd $1 million for 1,000 UNC employer class shares. This was comprised of $1 for each of the employer class shares accompanied by a $999 premium per share thus giving QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd its capital base of $1 million.

The beauty of it was that this $1 million was fully tax deductible to Advance Queensland Resources and Mining Pty Ltd, which is fully owned by QCMM Pty Ltd. In fact, the entire share premium balance in the accounts of QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd of $2.7 million was fully deductible to the owners of the 3,683 UNC employer class shares. At the centre of this tax web is the $2 million man and the minister for coal, Senator Parer. All the companies that perpetuated this tax manipulation—QCMM Pty Ltd, Advance Queensland Resources and Mining Pty Ltd and Tremell Pty Ltd, through the purchase of 3,683 UNC employer class shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd at a total cost of $2.7 million—did so under the guidance and instruction of Senator Parer and his wealthy mates.

Who was the director of QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd when 1,000 employee shares worth $10 on the same day became worth $1 million? It was Senator Parer. Who was the director of Advance Queensland Resources and Mining Pty Ltd when the decision was made to acquire $1 million worth of UNC employer class shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd? It was Senator Parer. Who was the director of QCMM Pty Ltd when the decision was made to acquire 570 UNC employer class shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd? It was Senator Parer. In essence, all tax avoidance roads lead to Senator Parer. That is basically how Senator Parer turned 44c into $56,300.

Some other issues need to canvassed in this tax manipulation saga. On what basis and how was it decided that Advance Queensland Resources would purchase $1 million worth of tax deductible employer class shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd? What did Advance Queensland get in return for this substantial transfer of money out of its coffers and into Senator Parer's and his six fellow directors' pockets?

Was an independent assessment carried out to determine whether the $1 million transfer was a suitable purchase or was it made purely for tax purposes? Did Advance Queensland seek an opinion from the Australian Taxation Office as to the bona fide arrangement regarding the purchase of one million employer class shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd? Did Senator Parer have to actively engage in work for the companies that purchased the UNC employer class shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd in order to qualify for his $56,300 worth of employee class shares for which he paid only 44c?

Lastly, let us look at Senator Parer's comments that QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd was in fact a superannuation type company. There was no doubt that it was a very generous and exclusive superannuation type company for Senator Parer and his six mates. How many battlers are able to invest $10 in the morning and be entitled to $1 million in the afternoon? None at all. Yet this government has ensured that the minuscule superannuation savings of battlers must now be included in determining their entitlement to social security benefits. Yet it is okay for the $2 million coal minister to turn 44c into $56,300 and the government to put this down to being a successful business man when in fact it is tax manipulation.

One may question why Senator Parer even needed to be in a superannuation type company when he is obviously a member of the parliamentary superannuation scheme. Senator Parer entered the Senate in 1985. When he was allocated his initial 12 one cent shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd in April 1994 he had been in the Senate for nine years and had therefore qualified for a parliamentary super pension. Given his re-endorsement, you would expect that Senator Parer would possibly be in the Senate until 2005 or in total 20 years. This 20 years would be comprised of two years as a minister and the balance as a backbencher. We know that he will be a minister for two years because we know that as soon as the poll driven Prime Minister (Mr Howard) sees the results of the Liberal Party focus groups Senator Parer will be left out to dry.

Here we have Senator Parer looking at receiving a parliamentary pension equivalent of 80 per cent of an MP's salary or probably just on $65,000 a year plus his $2 million coal investment plus his $56,300 in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd employee shares, for which he paid only 44 cents. Why then did Senator Parer need an employee share plan in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd when he had one through his parliamentary superannuation scheme? The answer is that it was tax manipulation and Senator Parer could not help himself but take part.

We saw the other day the plethora of government ministers and backbenchers who actively engage in income splitting and tax avoidance through their family trusts. Senator Parer has proved that he is no different. He is just another member of what is the wealthy ruling elite with its snout in the tax trough paid for at the expense of ordinary Australian PAYE workers.

Finally, I would note Senator Parer's comments that QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd stopped receiving contributions in 1995. Why was this so? Because the Labor Treasurer Ralph Willis closed down this manipulation in 1995 against a torrent of protests from the then Liberal opposition. Treasurer Willis said at the time in a press release:
The new taxation arrangements will serve to achieve our objective of removing the previously unlimited tax deferral opportunities for higher income earners.

This is exactly what Senator Parer was engaged in. If it was not for Labor's tax reform, no doubt Senator Parer would still be accumulating those extraordinarily generous employee shares in QCMM(ESP) Pty Ltd paid for by ordinary taxpayers.

talk.start.para: —I rise in this debate on matters of public importance to discuss the issue of young people and unemployment and refer in particular to a report that was released by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum last Friday entitled Australia's Youth: Reality and Risk . I wish to highlight the increasingly desperate plight of a growing proportion of Australia's young people. Despite years of promises and expansive statements by governments of both persuasions, little has eventuated in the form of real relief for the suffering many young people are experiencing.

speech.para: It is the sad truth that the road to this hell has been paved with good intentions. I note in an address to ACOSS in 1995 that the Prime Minister, John Howard, said to those gathered:
All Australians should have access to an adequate income, affordable housing, quality health care and a level of education that enables them to fully achieve their potential.

I am sure that most members in this place and, of course, the Australian Democrats could not agree more with these particular goals. Yet this government has failed to match its rhetoric with any real action to achieve them. It has brought Australia to a current situation where Australia's young people have shown to be suffering more than ever before.

I refer in particular to the release of quite a comprehensive report by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum last Friday entitled Australia's Youth: Reality and Risk. I know that I and other politicians in this place on all sides of the political spectrum were briefed on this report prior to its release. I think we are still awaiting a formal response or statement from government and perhaps from the opposition on some of the findings in this report. It is a comprehensive report dealing with the manifold ways in which young people lack opportunities—a failing on the part of society, contributed to by this government through its cutting back on education, training and employment opportunities for young Australians.

Figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics last week show that youth unemployment is still at an unacceptably high level of 26 per cent and that regional unemployment continues to rise. The report by the Dusseldorp Skills Forum reveals that almost 15 per cent of all 15- to 19-year-olds are not in full-time education or work—a proportion that has actually increased during the past decade.

The report does paint a rather bleak picture for the prospects of young people. In 1996 the number of unemployed 15- to 19-year-olds stood at 78,200. At the start of this year that number had risen to 88,500. In 1996, there were 67,800 15- to 19-year-olds in part-time work. By the start of this year the figure had risen to 78,900. We have discussed many times in this place the increasingly casualised nature of the work force. Where jobs have been created they are usually part-time or casual positions. We are really failing to address the issue of the provision of long-term, sustainable and meaningful jobs not just for young people but for people generally in our society.

The report tabled on Friday raises an even more worrying issue—that is, the number of young people who are simply not reflected in the official figures. We are conscious that the official rate is 26 per cent—and we all condemn that figure as unacceptably high—but more worrying are the number who are not considered in that estimate. The report estimates that as many as 25,000 young people have simply fallen through the holes in our social infrastructure. For every young person seeking work there is at least one other who is not counted in the official statistics.

We know that young people often find themselves disempowered or disenfranchised. Unlike previous generations, represented by many colleagues in this place, young people lack many of the opportunities afforded to the majority of Australians a decade ago. I do not underestimate some of the difficulties that confronted previous generations in many forms, but I think we have to accept that we have a radically different and restructured work force, for a number of reasons, and that youth unemployment is at almost unprecedented levels.

As the report states, young people face numerous challenges in their transition to adulthood and the spectre of unemployment looms large in frustrating many of their efforts to meet these. From completing education to leaving home and developing stable relationships, young people rely on finding long-term, meaningful employment to enable them to fulfil their potential. Yet the policies that have been implemented by this government in particular have prevented many young people doing just this. Instead of providing access to high quality education, we know that this government has cut funding to many of our education and training institutions—that is, at the primary, secondary and tertiary education levels. These cuts have directly advanced those already advantaged members of our society and usually, if not undoubtedly, at the expense of those who most need assistance. I have spoken many times in this place of the adverse impact that cuts to operating grants for universities have both on quality and access and equity. Certainly my colleague Senator Lyn Allison has spoken many times of her concerns and our party's concerns in the relation to the cuts to public education at the primary and secondary level.

Cuts in training programs and apprenticeships have also compounded this attack on access to skills development and education. We know that the key to a successful, an educated, a skilled and a competitive work force now and in the future will be effective education and training opportunities for all Australians, because education is increasingly a lifelong pursuit, as well as specifically for young Australians. I note we have three opportunities over the coming days in this place to address some of the changes that have been made to apprenticeships and traineeships in relation to cuts to the craft schemes. I think the opposition parties will seek to prevent the government making changes to the employer subsidy in relation to full-time apprenticeships.

There are also the recent changes to the common youth allowance which will affect especially lower middle income families, but which will again increase the financial burden and other burdens on families and reduce opportunities for many young people who are not in full-time employment, education and training.

Since coming to power, this government has been engaged in a sustained attack upon young people. As if the common youth allowance was not bad enough, young people must now contend with the imminent commencement of the new Job Network scheme. I say `imminent commencement' but I am just wondering exactly how many of the operators and providers will be up and running by 1 May with the necessary social infrastructure, support base and community links that they will need, if they are to tackle the seemingly intractable problem of unemployment and youth unemployment in particular.

Under the scheme, young people stand to be further disempowered in their search for employment and opportunities to fulfil their potential. Large numbers of young people will not be eligible for the common youth allowance, for example, because their parents earn more than the threshold at which the parental income means test kicks in—and at around $23,400 it is not even average weekly earnings; it is an extraordinarily low threshold at which to begin kicking-in for a parental means test. Those people will be either barred or have their payments reduced as a result of that parental means testing arrangement. These people will also find themselves barred from receiving real assistance from employment services providers.

The Dusseldorp Skills Forum report presents a number of proposals worthy of consideration and I commend them to this chamber. They include: prioritising marginalised young people, including those outside the labour market and those in part-time work, as well as those who are unemployed; recognising the need to better address the needs of early school leavers; placing a stronger emphasis on demand side policies in the labour market; reforming secondary education; and reforming vocational training to better address the needs of young people.

I have been rather concerned by the response to this report from both sides of politics, because many of the recommendations to which I have just referred are shared by people in this place. I see Senator Amanda Vanstone, who has talked many times about the need for reform in secondary education and about the need to match, in many cases, the education that we provide at a secondary level to the needs of not only the work force, but of young people, so that we cater more broadly and more diversely for the needs of young people in secondary education. So there is common ground on a number of these recommendations.

However, I noted the response of Dr Kemp, the minister responsible, to this report. It was that it was all Labor's fault. Labor's response, from their youth and education spokesperson, was that it was Dr Kemp's fault. Despite the fact that this is not really an issue about simply affording blame, no-one was prepared to accept that there were very real problems and very necessary recommendations in this report that required some response—even just a willingness to suggest, yes, this is a devastating problem and we will at least make some attempt to address the issues contained in the report. Rather than getting down to finding those solutions to the problem the report identified, both the old parties were engaged in a protracted buckpassing exercise. This political point scoring went no way to addressing some of the challenges in the labour market and the new challenges which may face young people and, of course, their families.

It is time for all politicians—all of us—to recognise that young people have enormous potential and should be given opportunities to realise this. Instead, young people are increasingly finding themselves blamed for the predicament in which they find themselves—for the lack of opportunities with which they are presented, and most often in an environment which serves only to disenfranchise or alienate them further.

It is little wonder that a Victorian education report came out about three weeks ago which suggests that young people's trust of politicians or their elected representatives is at an all-time low. I believe six per cent of young people trust us. It is no wonder that they feel so cynical and disillusioned when one report, perhaps the most comprehensive report in the last couple of years into the issues facing young Australians, has been met with such a disappointing and despondent response.

talk.start.para: —Today is a day of interesting coincidences because I had in fact been planning to give an address today on the Grafton meatworks and I will do that. But it is interesting because the sale of the meatworks was announced today by the local state member, Mr Harry Woods, in New South Wales. It is interesting because Mr Woods did not announce the sale price for the meatworks.

speech.para: Why is this matter of interest and why should it be of interest to the parliament of this country? Let me explain the problem which is faced. The meatworks at Grafton has been operated by a company called R.J.Gilbertson (Queensland) Pty Ltd and is part of a group of companies called the Gilbertson group. There was another company involved at the meatworks, a company called Giltech Pty Ltd, which employed about 50 people. For some period of time, these two companies had been part of a group of companies controlled by the Gilbertson family, which operated in the meat industry.

On 7 October last year, administrators were appointed under the Corporations Law to both R.J. Gilbertson (Queensland) Pty Ltd and Giltech Pty Ltd, and those administrators were Mr G.J. Kelly and Mr S.L. Horne of Clark and Co., who are chartered accountants in Melbourne.

Prior to this happening, a very peculiar thing occurred. Remember that the appointment of these administrators was on 7 October 1997. I am reliably informed that on 27 June 1997, two cheques were drawn in favour of other companies in the group from the accounts of one or other of these companies. One cheque was in the amount of $4,611,908.21. Another cheque, drawn on the same day, was in the amount of $1,233,981.96. These two payments alone total $5,845,890.17. Why, you may ask, were two cheques drawn on the same day to related companies in these massive amounts? I will get back to that. What is important to know is that the payments occurred at a time when the directors knew that these companies were probably insolvent. They certainly occurred within six months prior to the appointment of those administrators, which, as honourable senators will recall, occurred on 7 October 1997.

The administrators had to prepare a report for creditors. They prepared that report and presented that report to creditors, and that was dated 21 October last year. So they prepared the report within 14 days, and that was presented to a meeting of creditors of that company on 31 October last year.

The report is quite interesting because one of the obligations of the administrators is to investigate whether there have been any preferential payments, which are also called voidable dispositions. This is where a payment has been made to somebody who knows that the company which is making the payment is unable to meet its debts, and the payment has happened within the six months prior to the appointment of an administrator. It has the effect of giving the person who receives the payment a preference or an advantage over other people who are owed money by the company. Mr Stirling Horne of Clark and Co. cited section 588FA of the Corporations Law, and this is what he said about unfair preferences in his report:

This section of the Corporations Law provides for the recovery by a Liquidator of payments made by RJGQ to its creditors in the event that the company is wound up. Transactions that may be investigated are those made in the six months immediately prior to the commencement of the winding up which would be the date of the Administrator's appointment in this case.
A review of the creditors balances does not indicate any creditors received payment of their accounts ahead of other creditors.

All purchases and payments appear to have been made in the normal course of business with no suppliers threatening legal action. In the two weeks, prior to the appointment of Administrators I understand livestock suppliers had refused to allow the company to purchase further stock without a reduction in the debt. However, this situation generally applied to all livestock suppliers and again no one supplier appears to have been preferred.
Accordingly, I am of the opinion there were no unfair or other preferences of any material amount.

I think I have ably demonstrated that the two payments in question, which total some $5.8 million or more, are in fact prima facie preferences because they are paid to companies related to these in the group, at a time when the common directors knew these companies were in trouble—because they were about to apply for a release from the class order which governed the accounts of the group—and it had the distinct effect of preferring related companies over other creditors. Those other creditors included the employees of meatworks as well as local suppliers in the town of Grafton.

I think it was rather surprising that Clarke and Co. should form the view that they did. I think that most insolvency practitioners would have formed the contrary view. I think every insolvency practitioner I know would form the view that massive preferences existed here. I do not believe that Clarke and Co. acted with any mala fides at all. I think they were not aware of the full situation.

But what was the effect of that statement they made? The effect of that was to say to creditors, `You do not need to put these companies into liquidation. Put them under a deed of arrangement and you will get just as good an outcome if not better.' Of course by going into a deed of arrangement the effect of the deed was to prevent the creditors or a liquidator from going back and recovering that money. So in fact what has happened is that the creditors have been disadvantaged. Remember, the creditors include the workers and the local suppliers in the town of Grafton.

These matters were drawn to the attention of the Australian Securities Commission I understand as early as November last year. To the credit of the union they were drawn to the attention of the ASC by the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union, the Newcastle and northern branch I understand. That is to their credit.

It is a shame that I understand that the Australian Securities Commission took no action. It was not in fact until my colleague in the other place, the honourable member for Page, Mr Ian Causley, had his staff repeatedly contact the Australian Securities Commission that any action was taken by ASC relating to this matter. I understand though it is not just the $5.8 million that I have outlined here. I understand that preference payments could exceed $6 million. But not only did Mr Causley contact the Australian Securities Commission; he only contacted the scheme administrators, Clarke and Co., to say that he had very grave concerns about the matter.

In the interim Mr Causley has also provided me with documentation, including a letter sent by the union to ASC on 25 February this year and also material which was prepared by Clarke and Co., and I would not have been able to give this speech if it was not for Mr Causley's assistance in providing that information. When I saw the statement that was made in the circular to creditors dated 21 October, I was immediately concerned. So yesterday I contacted a representative of Clarke and Co. who admitted that they were not aware of the payments until Mr Causley drew them to their attention.

To their credit, however, they said that immediately they were aware of the payments they contacted the directors of the Gilbertson group and said that they thought there was a major problem. I think that was probably a understatement because if these payments go through and they are not recovered then the employees are out of pocket. The reason why the employees are out of pocket is because the ANZ I understand is owed around about $3.24 million. That was what it was owed on 7 October. I understand that interest has accrued in the interim and a payment may have been made to reduce it as well. But I understand the amount outstanding to the secured creditors is $3.2 million. They get first bite. They get first bite under legislation that was prepared by the previous government.

So if it is in fact the case as I suspect that the purchase price for this meatworks is in vicinity of $3.2 million, the only people who will get paid out will be the ANZ Bank, and the workers and the other unsecured creditors will be left with nothing. Of course, the Gilbertson group would also have the advantage of not having any liability for that $6 million in preference payments which may have been made.

Clarke and Co. as a result of Mr Causley's approaches to them, and also as result from pressure from Australian Securities Commission—and Mr Causley and the union have both written to Australian Securities Commission, but Mr Causley had contacted them on a number of occasions—then proceeded to contact the directors of the Gilbertson group and said, `Look, we think you had better do something about this because the whole deed could be set aside.' Honourable senators who are familiar with the operation of the Corporations Law would know that it is quite possible, even right now, for the court to order that the deed be set aside and a liquidator appointed to these companies to recover the amount of money.

I am pleased to tell the Senate that I was told yesterday by Clarke and Co. that an offer has now been made of a guarantee of further moneys outstanding to unsecured creditors from the Gilbertson group. This has been a direct result of the assiduous work of the honourable member for Page, Mr Causley, and a direct result of his pressuring both the Australian Securities Commission and Clarke and Co. to do something about this.

Why do I say that? Because yesterday, in a debate on another matter, I had to sit here and endure the usually tirade from Senator Forshaw who claimed that the members of the government and in particular the members of the National Party were doing nothing to look after the workers. Let me point out that while Senator Forshaw was grandstanding to the media, he was not doing any of hard work and was not actually looking after the interests of workers. He can thank the member for Page, Mr Causley, that that is now a possibility. But, it would wrong for me to say here and now that the matter is over. Because it is not.

There are a number of matters which now arise as a direct result of this offer of a guarantee. Let me run through those matters because they are very important. First of all, you have to know who is giving the guarantee, and that is not clear. Who would benefit under the guarantee? Will it be just the workers or will it also be all the other unsecured creditors in Grafton. I understand that they total in the vicinity of $3 million or more. So it is a massive loss, not just to workers but to small business people and to the cattle producers and so on.

Would the creditors be better off accepting this guarantee or would they be better applying for an order to set the deed aside and liquidating the companies, because it may well be that guarantee is worthless or the guarantee is not as good as the amount of money which could be recovered in event that companies were put into liquidation.

The other matters that have to be considered are how would it be administered and who would decide on the claims that unsecured creditors would make? It is quite obvious that Clarke and Co., for all their good efforts, are somewhat compromised because of this situation. It should not properly be adjudicating on the claims of unsecured creditors when the people who appointed them are the people who are probably giving the guarantee.

These matters I believe need to be resolved immediately. The reason why they need to be resolved immediately is that this sale has been announced but probably will not be completed for some weeks. In that period it is critical that another meeting of creditors be called at which all of the workers should have representation, and all of the small business suppliers as well. It should be at that meeting that a full and accurate and independent assessment of situation is provided to those unsecured creditors so that justice can be done in this case. We are close to achieving justice but until these matters are resolved, justice will not be done. I think if justice is finally done it will be in large part due to the efforts of my friend, the Hon. Ian Causley, and all the work he has done as well as, in large part, as a result of the work of the union. I think both of those deserve to be congratulated. But I warn that unless these matters are resolved there is remains the distinct possibility that workers and small business people in Grafton will remain hopelessly out of pocket.

subdebateinfo.title: Asian Economic Crisis: Tasmanian Tourism Industry

talk.start.para: —I want to talk about the Asian economic crisis and the impact it is having on the tourism industry, particularly the Tasmanian tourism industry. The effect of this crisis is already being felt in this key sector and I fear the worst is yet to come. That is certainly the view of the industry. For that reason, the Tourism Council of Australia has been pursuing the Howard government for months to help cushion the industry against the collapse in the number of Asian tourists.

speech.para: This is an industry that provides one in nine jobs. It contributes $60 billion to the domestic economy and $16 billion in export earnings. The March 1998 American Express Tourism Leading Indicators, a survey of industry expectations, showed business was expecting sales and profits to deteriorate in the March quarter, with job prospects to remain weak until September. Tourism Council Australia chairman, Bruce Baird, said the results of the survey highlighted the need for the federal government to act to support the industry. He said that negative growth in the industry was likely in the coming months as the Asian crisis fall-out fully affects arrival figures.

There was a similar view in a report from the Metal Trades Industry Association. The report, entitled The Economic Contest in 1998, states that tourism is already feeling the effects of the Asian crisis, with short-term arrivals slowing noticeably—and it forecasts worse to come. The report says that efforts by the industry to offset losses from South-East and North-East Asia, through increased numbers from China, Europe and America, will be very difficult. It says the reversal of growth in the South-East Asian and Hong Kong markets is even more damaging because spending per visit of these tourists is on the high side—a combination of more spending per night and longer stays. The evidence is there for all to see and the impact is already being felt. But so far the industry's quite legitimate call for assistance from Mr Howard has largely fallen on deaf ears.

The package the Tourism Council of Australia is asking Mr Howard to support includes three key strategies. First, the introduction of a 12-month visa-free trial for selected markets, including the United Kingdom, the USA and Singapore. According to the Council, the current visa policy is costing up to 15 per cent of our potential Japanese market and costs more than $45 million a year to administer. Secondly, a one-off campaign designed to boost domestic tourism in partnership with the states and the territories—the `Holiday at Home' campaign. And finally, a strategy to grow emerging markets, such as China and India.

Government support for this key sector of the economy is very important nationally, but it is vital from a Tasmanian perspective. A report prepared by Tourism Tasmania last year, which was based on 1995 data, shows just how important this sector is to the Tasmanian economy. In that year, visitors to the state spent $857 million on travel, the industry employed between 13,500 and 18,700 people and contributed between 5.8 and 8.3 per cent of the gross state product.

Three industry groups accounted for more than 70 per cent of the jobs created by tourists. They were the wholesale, retail and insurance industry; restaurants and hotels; and the entertainment and recreation industry. A key feature of the employment generated by the tourist sector in Tasmania is the wide distribution of its benefits. The study found that more than half the employment was generated in the southern region, 30 per cent in the northern region and 19 per cent in the north-west. The economic benefits are also spread throughout the state, with the small business sector being a big winner. Without a properly funded and marketed plan, the Tasmanian industry is badly exposed to the Asian crisis.

While a reduction in the number of international visitors will not have a direct impact in Tasmania, it will certainly have an indirect effect. The decline in international visitors in Queensland—particularly in Cairns—will see heavy discounting of airfares and accommodation in the north to build up domestic visitations. If successful, that strategy could hit Tasmania hard and the leakage of domestic travel into relatively cheap Asian destinations will only add to these problems.

This trend is likely to strengthen over the coming months, especially after May. Not only is May the month when the industry in Tasmania expects the difficult market conditions to bite, it is also the month when the Howard government delivers its third budget. This budget holds the key to the future of this key industry. With the right support, tourism will continue to earn millions of dollars in export income and to generate thousands of new jobs. If the government does not financially reinforce the strategies the industry has put in place to counter the Asian downturn, then the sector is in for a tough time.

The future welfare of the Tasmanian industry is heavily dependent on interstate visitations. In 1995, 76 per cent of holiday travellers came from interstate, with intrastate travellers accounting for just under 10 per cent and international travellers 14 per cent. From a local point of view, the planned `Holiday at Home' campaign is a key to minimising the anticipated downturn. The campaign would focus on encouraging more Australians to holiday at home instead of travelling overseas. The efforts of Tourism Council of Australia to further boost the number of tourists from the traditional markets of the United Kingdom, the USA and Europe would also help Tasmania.

Investment in tourism is money well spent because of the number of jobs generated. Investment in promoting tourism is money well spent in that each dollar spent generates eight dollars for the economy. Governments also get a good return from their investment through taxation revenue. The Tasmanian tourism study found that in 1995 government tax revenues from tourism in Tasmania amounted to an estimated $287 million, with about 73 per cent going to the federal government, 22 per cent to the Tasmanian government and 5 per cent of the revenue going to Tasmanian local government authorities.

Last year was a boom year for the industry in Tasmania. Just under half a million tourists visited the state. There was a 7.7 per cent increase in international tourist visitors, with a 9.6 per cent increase in Asian tourist visits, excluding Japanese. There was a 2.7 per cent increase in interstate visitors.

I have noted that the Tasmanian tourism minister, Mr Groom, was quoted in the Launceston Examiner as saying that he was quietly confident that the 1998 tourism season would produce even better results. I hope he is right but, frankly, I fear that he is not going to be right on that score. Certainly, his prediction will not be realised unless there is a concerted effort by the industry, the state government and the Commonwealth government to put in place a strategy to insulate Tasmania from the Asian crisis.

This is not a time to sit back. It is certainly not a time to take the approach promoted by the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, John Moore. Mr Moore said on ABC television, in response to calls by the tourism industry for support to help beat the Asian crisis:
If they're—
by `they' he meant the airlines—
not filling the seats, then don't run the planes.
His comments came as the government announced a $300 million rescue package for exporters to Indonesia through the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation.

Mr Acting Deputy President, if the airlines don't fill their seats and they then do not fly their planes, then the hotels and motels do not fill their rooms, the restaurants do not sell meals, service stations do not sell petrol and other small businesses do not sell their goods and services. Then they all start laying off workers. Let us hope Mr Moore sees some sense before the next budget in May. Otherwise states like my state of Tasmania will pay heavily for this indifference.

There are two other issues the Howard government has put on the agenda that are having a significant impact on the tourism industry, particularly in Tasmania. They are, firstly, the threat of a goods and services tax; and, secondly, the constant threat of an early election. Both these issues are creating considerable uncertainty in the community and people are less likely to spend money on a holiday as a result. Mr Howard's GST will also turn tourist operators into tax collectors. According to the President of the National Tax and Accountants Association, Mr Ray Regan, the GST will cost small businesses at least $7,000 a year in compliance costs, and will require at least 228 hours to meet monthly compliance requirements. This is just what the Tasmanian tourism industry does not need.

In the upcoming budget Mr Howard should do two things to help the tourism industry. He should give it the financial support it needs and he should rule out a GST. He should also stop fuelling election speculation every time he does not get his way in the Senate. It is very bad for business, especially the tourism business in Tasmania.

In closing, I want to say that following the division this morning on what is being touted as a double dissolution bill—the Workplace Relations Amendment Bill 1997 [No. 2]—one of the government senators, after the announcement of the vote, punched the air in an indication of exultation or triumph. I think it is important to put that on the record because I think it demonstrates the approach of this government to that legislation. It is very distressing for industries, like the tourism industry, to see the games being played about legislation that will impact on their industry if this government isn't very careful.

talk.start.para: —I rise to make the first of a series of three speeches dealing with my continuing study of the rapidly changing world of information technology. IT is constantly changing and it is very important that Australia keeps abreast of the latest overseas developments.

speech.para: Four years ago I visited the US, to examine the information superhighway—at that time it was a relatively new concept to Australia. Digital broadcasting and interactive television was then a dream of the future but now, of course, it is ready to go. The Internet back then was a new concept that most Australians did not understand. Nowadays, people will actually give you their home page number—big changes in a relatively short time.

In 1994 I called for Australia to take account of these converging new technologies. I called for the introduction of one broad act which would allow open competition and movement of services across different technologies and businesses to take advantage of business opportunities that this new age created. Just as I believed in 1994 that we must ensure universal access to this technology to make sure that there was not a developing underclass in Australia, I also made the point at that time that there was an opportunity for Australia to become the information hub of South-East Asia.

Australia has many advantages in this regard in the new information age. We are politically stable, we have a highly educated population and a single communications structure which moves across major population centres. These are based around the south-east corner of Australia where up to 80 per cent of the population live in a narrow crescent between Brisbane and Adelaide. We have highly developed information technology and a very high take up rate of that technology.

Therefore, three and a half years on, it was very useful to visit one of our neighbours—Malaysia—which also felt that it should become an information hub for the whole South-East Asian region. Recently, in Kuala Lumpur, I met with industry executives and government officials who were involved in information technology. Malaysia is in high-speed mode to get its multimedia super corridor—the MSC—operational. They claim to be 10 years ahead of their time, which actually makes Australia's failed multifunction polis in Adelaide of 20—or was it 10 years ago—

talk.start.para: —Ten years is better.

—Twenty years ahead of its time, perhaps, Senator Schacht. The MSC concept is, in many ways, similar to the multifunction polis but with two very significant differences. Malaysia in 1998 is starting this on the cusp of the information age and, unlike the ALP's stewardship of the MFP from the mid-eighties to the mid-nineties, Malaysia's MSC is part of their 2020 vision for their nation and is driven from the top, by Malaysia's Prime Minister.

speech.para: The multimedia super corridor is being sold as the region's launch site for companies developing and using multimedia technology. This is competition for Australia and Malaysia is pushing itself as the location for multinationals in this sort of industry across the region. It is important, then, that we in Australia keep track of how the Malaysian multimedia super corridor is progressing. Senator Alston visited Malaysia about 12 months ago and in that short time, things have progressed significantly.

You would think the project's high speed would be slowed by Asia's economic meltdown—not so. The Malaysian government is so keen for this project to get going that they have quarantined it from any budgetary cuts. The Malaysian government has cut its expenditure by 18 per cent but nothing came off the MSC funding. I was told the Malaysian government sees this project as the key to its future. The MSC is a 15 by 50 kilometre zone extending south from Kuala Lumpur to the new airport. It includes building two new cities, one known as Cyberjaya—cyber city—which will house businesses and workers. The government plans to base itself in a new city next door called Putrajaya which will be the new administrative centre of Malaysia.

The MSC will bring together four elements. It will bring together firstly, leading edge software infrastructure, including highly attractive incentives; unrestricted import of foreign knowledge; the world's first comprehensive framework of `cyberlaws' and the world's first multimedia convergence legislation. Secondly, world class IT networks consisting of a high-speed backbone network and cost-competitive telecommunications tariffs will be put in place. Thirdly, a multimedia development corporation will be created and this will ensure that companies interested in locating in the MSC can get what they need to succeed and will expedite permit and licence approvals. Fourthly, this will all be done in an environment of top quality urban development in Cyberjaya.

It is ultimately planned that this city will house 240,000 people—about the size of Canberra. It is estimated that 500 information technology and multimedia companies will be located in Cyberjaya by the year 2020. I was told by several sources that 116 international companies have already signed up to locate in the MSC. The Malaysian government has put together a number of commitments to companies interested in coming on board. These include the incentive for unrestricted employment of local and foreign knowledge workers; freedom of ownership so that total foreign control of firms is actually welcomed; a five-year exemption from Malaysian income tax, renewable to 10 years or 100 per cent investment tax allowance on new investments made in the MSC cybercities. In addition, government officials, including the Malaysian Minister for Communications, said that the country should have its convergence act in place by the middle of the year—a broad act to create a very flexible environment for new business. I was told during the meetings with industry and government officials that other areas in Malaysia also want to establish MSCs with Penang already fairly well advanced.

This is a huge project and it is important to Australia that we are aware of what is happening in Malaysia in this international context. I will look forward to sharing with the Senate what else I discovered and other aspects of this dawning information age in future MPI speeches.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, do you recall that you told the Senate yesterday in relation to the QCMM Group (ESP):

question.para: I have never had any involvement in what that company puts money into . . . I have no control over it and never have had any control over it—

Minister, isn't it actually true that on at least eight occasions you chaired meetings of QCMM Group (ESP) which discussed allotting 1,000 employer shares to AQRM, putting money into Bruce Resources, the impact on ESP shares of Tomen's takeover of AMI and which authorised you to sign off on the annual financial statements? Do you still maintain, as you said yesterday, that you have no involvement and no control? Minister, why did you mislead the Senate again? Will you now correct the record?

talk.start.para: —Here we have a regurgitation of this over and over again. You are at the bottom of the barrel, Senator. What I said is that I had no involvement in the decision making process, certainly in relation to the time that I got out of it. I had very little involvement in the past. Certainly for the official returns you have to sign off on them. Let me also say, because I suspect there will be some more questions coming from the other side, that this was set up as a retirement type fund.

answer.para: During the debate on matters of public interest Senator Cook came in here and tipped a bucket, or tried to tip a bucket all over me. Normal courtesies in this place are—whether you do it in a public interest debate or an adjournment debate—that you let the other person know that you are going to do it. All I can say is that you people on the other side have sunk to absolute lows.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I asked Senator Parer a direct question about a statement that he made to the Senate yesterday which I believe was a deliberate and serious misleading of the Senate. Senator Parer may well want to respond to something else that was said at another time. There are plenty of opportunities, as you are aware, Madam President, that he can take if he cares to do so, not the least of which is a personal explanation at the appropriate time. But I do think on this occasion you ought to direct the minister to answer what is a very serious question that I have directed to him about his misleading the Senate yesterday.

—Madam President, on the point of order: an even much more serious matter is Senator Faulkner's consistent use of points of order to effectively impugn the integrity of other senators. His question was: why did you deliberately mislead the Senate yesterday? He then got up and said that he believed that Senator Parer had deliberately misled the Senate. He is simply using points of order as a vehicle for saying things that are quite contrary to standing orders. That should not be allowed. There is no point of order, of course. He does not even purport to have one because Senator Parer has not even started to answer the question. He is simply abusing the processes of this place and he should not be allowed to continue.

—Senator Parer has been answering the question, and I do not know whether anything that Senator Cook raised relates to this or not. So I cannot comment on whether the remarks arising from that are relevant to this answer or not. I would draw Senator Parer's attention to the question that has been asked of him.

—Everyone knows in this particular chamber—and, from the scurrilous campaign waged by Senator Faulkner and others, I assume everyone in Australia knows—that I was on the board and was chairman of the Queensland Coal Mine Management companies and all subsidiaries. They also know that when I was appointed as a minister I resigned from those and had no involvement whatsoever in the operation of either the Queensland Coal Mine Management company or its subsidiaries. The people on the other side tried to run the line that I did. They said that I went to Japan. There was a scurrilous article in the Sydney Morning Herald that said I had met with one of the major trading companies and, as a result of that, additional coal sales contracts. The dope who wrote that did not even realise that the group I spoke to do not buy coal. They are a trading company.
—Sue him because we were not behind that one.

—Good idea, Senator Ray. Then they were running the line saying, `Have you met with Mr Shand? What did you talk about?' That has been totally debunked. You are running this technical question saying that I somehow misled the Senate deliberately. I can assure you, Senator, I did not. The point I made yesterday was that I had no involvement, and the implication is since I actually resigned from those boards. Naturally I did because I was there up until that time and everyone knows that.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, yesterday you said to the Senate—let me quote you again:

question.para: I have never had any involvement in what that company puts money into . . . I have no control over it and never have had any control over it—
Now you are reinterpreting that answer. You do accept that that was a mislead yesterday, do you, Senator Parer? Do you stand by your statement, Senator Parer, of yesterday in question time?

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I ask that you direct Senator Faulkner to direct his questions through you and not scream them across the chamber at Senator Parer.
—Questions should be addressed to the chair.
—I ask the minister whether he stands by his statement yesterday:

question.para: I have never had any involvement in what that company puts money into . . . I have no control over it and never have had any control over it—
Minister, do you stand by your statement in question time yesterday?

talk.start.para: —I stand by the statement that I have made over and over again that I was involved with those companies up until the day I was appointed a minister. I resigned all positions and have had no involvement with them whatsoever since.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators of the presence in the gallery of a parliamentary delegation from Papua New Guinea led by the Speaker of the National Parliament, Mr John Pundari MP. On behalf of honourable senators I welcome you to the Senate and wish you a happy and enjoyable visit to this country. With the concurrence of the Senate I invite the Speaker to take a seat on the floor.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. It relates to Australia's anti-jobs unfair dismissal laws which today were supported by the Australian Labor Party. What will be the impact on job creation as a result of this action?

—Yes, it is extraordinary that the Labor Party is opposed to the creation of jobs. The way the Labor Party continues to oppose the interests of small business is also extraordinary. They have not learnt a thing. They have not learnt the necessity to create an economy in which small business is free enough to grow, expand and create employment opportunities. Anti-jobs is the Labor position. Anti small business is the Labor position.

answer.para: One would have thought that they would have listened. The evidence was overwhelming. They could have listened to what was put forward through the Yellow Pages Small Business Index, which showed that 79 per cent of small businesses thought that small business would be better off if exempted from the unfair dismissal laws. Thirty-three per cent said that small business would be more likely to recruit new employees had there been such an exemption, and 33 per cent of small businesses said they would be more likely to recruit new employees if they were exempt from the current unfair dismissal laws. So there is the evidence from small business itself.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Madam President. Is the minister referring to federal laws in that survey or to state laws?
—There is no point of order.

—If they were not prepared to listen to small business as expressed through the Yellow Pages survey, perhaps they could have listened to the state chamber of commerce in New South Wales, which surveyed 700 small businesses. They said that 42 per cent of businesses believed unfair dismissal laws were a deterrent to employing more staff. An overwhelming 85 per cent of small businesses nominated unfair dismissal laws as a key factor affecting businesses with 15 or fewer employees. If they do not want to look at the statistics, they could have listened to what the chamber said.
—Common rule awards.

interjection.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Hill. There are far too many people interjecting on my left. I ask them to desist.

—I know this is embarrassing for Labor. They do not want to be seen as the anti-jobs party. They do not want to be seen as the anti small business party. But the evidence is overwhelming. They could have listened to the chamber of commerce saying that `the small business community is the engine room of job creation and it is crying out for relief from what it sees as an impediment to employing people and growing small and medium-sized companies'. But of course the new Labor Party simply will not listen.

answer.para: If they did not want to listen to the chamber of commerce from New South Wales they could have listened to the fact that 50 small business organisations referred to under the umbrella of the Small Business Coalition all met in Canberra last month and unanimously said that the exemption should be passed in the interests of small business and more jobs. Or they could have listened to the Council of Small Business Organisations, which indicated even this week that 50,000 jobs would be created in small business if the exemption law were passed. Fifty thousand jobs: I would have thought that that would have caused the Labor Party to stand up and listen, but they will not. What are they embarrassed about? Is it the fact that the coalition, by contrast, has created 220,000 new jobs since it came into office? Are they embarrassed by the fact that they have asked only three employment questions in 88 sitting days? Why is the Labor Party so disinterested in job creation? Why isn't the Labor Party interested in supporting small business, freeing them up so they have the opportunity to grow and to employ more Australians, particularly young Australians? Those Australians out of work will be very disappointed by the Labor Party of today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Madam President. Why is it that yesterday when the Leader of the Opposition was on his feet we were repeatedly asked on this side to be in entire silence while he was speaking? Why is it that the Leader of the Government is not accorded the same treatment in the Senate by the chair and particularly by those opposite who expect silence for their own speakers.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, can you confirm that QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd was established as nothing more than a tax lurk to enable QCMM Pty Ltd and its fully owned subsidiary, Advance Queensland Resources and Mining Pty Ltd, to claim hundreds of thousands of dollars in tax deductions through the purchase of UNC employer class shares in QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd? Minister, how is that you are able to qualify for an employee share plan offered by QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd when you are not an employee but a full-time senator? How is it that your 44 shares in QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd issued to you for 1c each in what you term a superannuation type company became worth $56,300 in the space of a few years?

—I have already answered the question here a number of times. In fact, I made it very clear. This ESP is the employees' share plan. It was available to certain directors and shareholders. I have said that right from the word go.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is directors and employees. And they were ones selected, I might tell you, by the three major shareholders, the three owners of the operation—
—Employees?
—Order! Senators on my left will cease interjecting.

—Let me say that this ESP was established on professional advice as an employee sponsored investment plan. The share issue did not really matter. Those were the people who qualified, hence they had to take shares. It was actually put out as an alternative to superannuation, and a holding is akin to a preserved benefit. As I said in here yesterday, certainly when the company makes those contributions it gets a tax deduction. The way it was set up was some formula—bear in mind I was not the chief executive; I was the chairman—based on profitability. I said this again yesterday—
—Senator Parer, would you resume your seat? There is far too much noise on my left. I require senators to abide by the standing orders.

—As I said yesterday, if you are prepared to listen, because of the way the company itself was set up it pays tax on any investments on which it gets a return. When the amount is withdrawn on retirement as a retirement benefit, full taxation is paid. Let me also say, because here you are talking about scams, Senator Cook, the professional advice received at the time was that these types of retirement benefit funds were approved by the taxation commissioner.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I note that you said that you were not the executive, but the chairman. I understand the buck stops with the chairman. I refer you to your statement in regards to QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd that contributions made to that ceased in 1995. Minister, isn't the reason they ceased due to the fact that, in 1995, Treasurer Ralph Willis outlawed such arrangements because they allowed `unlimited tax deferral opportunities for higher income earners'—such as yourself? Minister, rather than being a tax lurk, isn't it true that QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd was nothing more than a tax rort? Doesn't this explain your failure to declare your 44 1c shares held by QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd that are now worth $56,300?

—Senator Cook, the answer to your question is no. I made this point very clear from the beginning. My reading of this was that it was a retirement type benefit. There was no deliberate attempt to do anything in that way. In regard to the scheme itself, as to the reason it ceased, Senator, I am not aware. I do not recall it. All I know is that it was decided not to continue with it. But the professional advice received at the time had the blessing of the taxation commissioner.

—My question is to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations. The minister would be aware that the Maritime Union of Australia is pursuing a politically motivated payback through an unnecessary seven-day strike in Sydney to punish Patrick Stevedoring. Is the minister aware of a report that identifies Sydney as the worst port surveyed bar one—number 17 out of 18—and will this seven-day strike further damage Sydney's reputation, already damaged by the inefficient work practices of the Maritime Union?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Senator Tierney is quite right that, in the recent survey, in terms of value for money, Sydney came in second last—17 out of 18. But, when they included reliability and speed, the Bureau of Industry Economics report found that Sydney came in dead last. This is the very port where this union—this greedy, grubby silvertail union, with people earning $100,000-plus—is now going on strike claiming even more money for less work.

answer.para: Why are they doing it? Because they have had legal advice that, unless they at least pretend that it is a claim related to earnings, they have no justification at all. But, in fact, of course, they have no justification, full stop. We know from the recent little strip show effort a couple of months ago that these boys, who are only able to work about 15 cranes an hour, when told that they could knock off early to get down to the strip show at the pub were able to get that up to 29.4 loads an hour. An absolute explosion of work! It is a wonder they were not all on sick leave the following day. They must have been exhausted. Of course, they were not. They had hardly worked up a sweat, because that is about what you ought to be able to do if you are serious about it.

Of course, they have never been serious, and nor have the Labor Party. This is the crowd that went down to Hobart a few months ago and said that they believed in waterfront reform. They said they would encourage greater competition through new stevedoring operations. What have we heard? Not a peep! When Mr McMullan was asked whether the MUA has the Labor Party's unequivocal support, he said, `Well, it's not a question of unequivocal support.' I do not know what it is. What it really is is: `Keep your head down. Don't come here and ask questions.' We have not had a word about Patricks here, have we, because they do not want to raise the issue. They are terminally embarrassed by this. Lindsay Tanner is out there saying, `We can't defend the indefensible'—that is his position—`but we'll say as little as possible and hope no-one notices.' This is gutlessness at its highest, Madam President.

The fact is that Mr Beazley's position is that he wants to call in Bob Hawke. What would Bob Hawke do? Bob Hawke happens to be the bloke who, in 1989, when he was presiding over the pilots strike, said, `This mob will cop every instrument of punishment and retribution. It's a different game this time, boys. It's war. They are exceptionally greedy.' Surely those words apply. Those words apply in spades to the MUA, so why won't Labor stand up and criticise them? Why does Labor tolerate the airconditioning rorts where everyone goes out if the temperature gets to 39 degrees celsius outside, even if you are freezing to death inside?

This is the mob that supports the safety card rort where, the moment you want to put pressure on a shipowner, you claim that the gangway is a bit unsafe. They support the car loading rort. We have two security wharfies, one first aid wharfie and two wharfie clerks watching cars being unloaded. Has Labor criticised any of these? Of course they have not, Madam President. They stand shoulder to shoulder with the MUA. They know full well that is unconscionable and outrageous. But, no, because they are told that they have got to stand in support, they do it.

This is the greatest conflict of interest in history, Madam President. Let there be no misunderstanding. When nine out of the last 10 Labor senators in this place have trade union affiliations, when two-thirds of them are locked into the trade union movement, what else can you expect? It is an outrage. They ought to come clean about it and say they are not prepared to do anything that would jeopardise the interests of the trade union movement. They are certainly doing it by their actions. Why don't they come clean and say it in words? The public of Australia already know it, but they would like to hear it so they know precisely where you stand on this issue.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. It is very interesting that the people opposite, Minister, show absolutely no interest in a real issue that is concerning Australians and are just interested in character assassination. How does this Maritime Union strike action contribute to the process of waterfront reform and improve the living standards of all Australians, not just the silvertails in the Maritime Union?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The last time that Bob Hawke had a chance to do something about the waterfront, it cost taxpayers $420 million. What return did we get for that? Some of them are still back there, having taken their redundancy pay, working at half pace. It is quite clear that Labor has no interest in job creation, no interest in export competitiveness. This is all about trying to improve productivity.

answer.para: Why won't you stand up and argue for productivity on the waterfront? You were prepared to kick the pilots to death, but you are not prepared to say boo to the puppet masters on this one, are you, because you know that the MUA does not have any friends in the wider community. But, because it rattles the tin at election time, because it will come to the party if you keep quiet, you are more than happy to see the money laundered through it. It is a damning indictment of Labor's total lack of interest in real productivity and job creation. If you got efficiency on the waterfront, you would make a very significant difference to manufacturing competitiveness. That is the last thing you are interested in doing. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a delegation from Botswana, led by the Minister for Agriculture, Mr Ronald Sebego. On behalf of honourable senators I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

interjection.para: I would also take the opportunity to welcome to the Senate former distinguished Tasmanian senator Mr Brian Archer.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!

—Through you, Madam President, to Senator Parer: Minister, were you present at a meeting of QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd held on 24 April 1994 in Brisbane where you were issued 12 1c employee shares out of a total of 1,000 employee shares worth a total of 12c? Can you confirm that on the same day your employee contribution account of QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd was credited with an amount of $12,000? Minister, is it also true that your employee contribution account and those of six other individuals were credited with a total of $1 million on 28 April? Will you also confirm this $1 million employee contribution account was funded through a $1 million tax deduction claim by the QCMM Pty Ltd group through the purchase of 1,000 $1 UNC employer class shares at a premium of $990 per share in QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd? Is this a rort or not? (Time expired)

—Obviously, both Senator Cook and Senator Faulkner have a clear advantage over me. Where their clear advantage over me is, when I resigned as chairman and director of all those companies, I got rid of all the records. You have stolen documents. That is what you have.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! We will proceed with question time when order is restored to the chamber.
—I made it very clear as to how that QCMM (ESP) operated. It was a retirement type scheme which was approved, as I understand, on professional advice at the time.
—You were in the Senate.

—It does not matter whether you are in the Senate or not. It was a retirement type scheme. It was available to employees and directors. It was a system whereby a certain amount of profits was put into the program. The whole idea of it was to be as a retirement type benefit. As I pointed out—I do not know how often I have to say this—it goes into the company, the company makes investments, it pays tax on the investments and, when you take your money out, you pay full tax.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. That is a very interesting answer, Minister. We will deal with that. Minister, can you also confirm that your initial allocation of 12 1c shares is now in fact 44 1c shares? Was it just convenient, or did you forget to declare those 44 1c shares in QCMM (ESP) Pty Ltd when, by your own admission, they are now worth $56,300?

—I have explained in the Senate—and I think it was last week—that I looked on that as being a retirement type benefit. Under the rules, as I knew them, I would be only too happy to declare them once these were made known to me. There has been no other comment that I have made about that. That is quite true, Senator.

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. I refer to media reports of closed door negotiations between the government and the opposition which may see Labor backing down on key sticking points in the Native Title Amendment Bill next week. Will you confirm that these negotiations are taking place? Will you tell the Senate whether they are being held directly with the Labor leadership through Gareth Evans's office, thus sidestepping their spokesman Daryl Melham? Will you confirm these talks are the real reason behind the government's curious decision not to list the bill for debate this week, even though it was exempted from the cut-off rule 14 days ago because you claimed that it was vitally urgent?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —It is true to say that the government takes a very sensible, cooperative approach to the Native Title Amendment Bill. We want this bill passed by the Senate. We are not looking for a double dissolution, unlike some of our opponents. We want the Native Title Amendment Bill passed by the parliament to restore certainty in land management to the whole of Australia—including to Western Australia, the state of the ALP leader, who is selling out his state in the interests of the Left in Sydney and Melbourne. We will not compromise on the four remaining sticking points. They are, as you know, the right to negotiate, the sunset clause and the Racial Discrimination Act.
—That is three. What is the fourth one?

—The registration test, in case you had forgotten. We are prepared to discuss with other parties ways of achieving the outcomes the government desires in a way that is acceptable to all parties. We have set a minimum standard that we will not compromise because this act must be made workable, and the current act is unworkable. We have said that there are standards that must be met but, in the spirit of cooperation, for which this government is famous, we are prepared to discuss ways to achieve those outcomes that do not water down the bill in any way. So there have indeed been discussions at officials' level with the ALP and with Senator Harradine's advisers to see if there is any way in which those parties can be persuaded to accept the standards that we have set in order to see this bill passed, because we do not want a double dissolution, unlike some of the lunatics on the other side.

answer.para: Regrettably, the Democrats and the Greens have completely dealt themselves out of this debate because you are just retreating to the position adopted by the National Indigenous Working Group. You are going to crawl into this chamber and just put forward those ludicrous amendments which are no advance on the position they put down in April last year. One of the fundamental positions the National Indigenous Working Group have is that there should be an absolute Aboriginal veto on development on 79 per cent of Australia. That is a statement in the famous yellow book that you are endorsing. The Democrats and the Greens have dealt yourselves right out of this debate by your position of retreating to that document, which does not allow any basis for sensible consultation, negotiation or discussion as to how we advance this debate. We want the bill through. If you want to deal yourselves back into the debate, then get away from the Indigenous Working Group position, which is utterly untenable, unworkable and unacceptable.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, on a point of order: during the minister's response he referred to the `lunatics on the other side'.

interjection.para: Government senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right will obey the standing orders.

—Madam President, I know there has been a struggle recently to maintain control in this place. I suggest that, if words like that are left on the record and become acceptable parliamentary terms, we will all in the future suffer because of it. I think the words ought to be withdrawn and ruled as being unparliamentary for now and for the future.
—I agree with that and would ask that the words be withdrawn.
—I did not realise Senator McKiernan was so sensitive to such a term.
—Senator Minchin, I asked you to withdraw.
—I am happy to withdraw. I was merely quoting Alan Ramsey, who referred to the `looney left'.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, the Democrats do not want a double dissolution either, but we are not prepared to sign a blank cheque so you can short-change the first Australians over native title just to avoid one. Does the indigenous community have a seat at the table at these talks, not second- or third-hand reports but directly on either your team or Gareth Evans's team of negotiators? Finally, isn't the only minor consolation in this matter the fact that Senator Bob Collins, a man of great passion on this issue, will avoid the humiliation of rubber-stamping a deal in this chamber next week by dint of his impending resignation?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Can I say that, regrettably, we have offered you briefings and discussions about some of the sticking points in relation to the bill but there does not seem to be much of a response. We are certainly keeping all parties informed in response to their requests to be kept informed. So legal representatives of ATSIC and the Indigenous Working Group are properly being kept informed of the discussions in relation to the sticking points between the parties. It is the Indigenous Working Group that walked away from the table last May. They were the ones who walked away from the government. The government has been open to consultation with ATSIC and the Indigenous Working Group throughout this process. They left the table. They walked away from it. We are keeping them informed, as they request and as they desire, as to the discussions that we are having about technical amendments in an attempt to resolve differences between the parties in the Senate. So our good faith has been exhibited.

—My question is directed to Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, why haven't you made a full declaration of your family's trust's shareholdings to the Registrar of Senators' Interests as you promised to do on numerous occasion. I remind you that it is now 14 days since your flouting of the parliament's requirements was made public, yet you have continued your flagrant breach. Minister, do you intend to make a full declaration, or will you be hiding your pecuniary interests behind your decision to transfer interests to your family members, despite this disguise being clearly contrary to the Prime Minister's now discredited code of conduct?
—That deserves a serious answer, because I did say here I would make full disclosure, bearing in mind that I was unaware of the letter—
—Two letters.

—We were unaware of those; I think you will accept that that was the case. I was unaware of those and I said I would make full disclosure. Other things have occupied my mind a little over the past two weeks, but let me tell you that the intent is to get those declarations in this week and, when I put them in, I will put them in based both on the position as it is now and the position as it was last week.
—Before Thursday's question time?
—That is the intent.
