talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Workplace Relations Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 314 and made under the Workplace Relations Act 1996, be disallowed.

Before I begin, I acknowledge the advice that the minister's office has given to me on these regulations and the cooperation of the officers in the advisers box. This is a welcome change from the way in which we get responses from this government, and I thank the minister for that assistance. I am not altogether certain that he will thank me for my understanding of that assistance.

The Workplace Relations Act 1996 provided for the education ministers to make regulations in regard to approving authorities for apprenticeships and traineeships. They provided that any state or territory training authority and industry training advisory body, or any other body which meets the requirements set out in those regulations, could make orders in regard to those matters relating to the approving authority. The regulations that we have before us also go to allowing state and territory training authorities to delegate their powers and their functions as approving authorities to other bodies.

The government has sought to provide criteria under which such bodies should make determinations in regard to traineeships and apprenticeships. This went to the questions of whether there was adequate industry support, knowledge of the industry, knowledge of the competency approach to training, whether there was a capacity to have a protection against conflict of interest and a capacity to comply with the law. None of that is particularly surprising.

My concern, however, is with the detail and the way in which these measures work in practice. My concern is where this government is moving in terms of the operations of the vocational education and training system in this country. I am particularly concerned about the impact of these regulations on the issues arising from the conflict of interest that exists and the government's proposed strat egies to manage those conflicts of interest where they do exist. The contention that I put to the Senate is that the strategies are not adequate to protect the interests of workers undertaking training and apprenticeship arrangements under these regulations.

We have to appreciate that the government's actions in this regard have to be seen in the broader context of the massive changes that are occurring to the vocational education and training system. We have a system of vocational education and training in this country which the government's own preferred and favourite consultant, KPMG, has indicated is totally under funded. You have a situation where the government is introducing a massive revamp of the apprenticeship system. They are introducing their so-called new apprenticeship scheme, which suggests, in regard to the massive advertising campaign they are running to support this program, massive growth in traineeships at the expense of traditional apprenticeship models of training. You have a government that talks increasingly of flexibility. But we have had a series of regulations before us today which would open the door to lower quality training and lower wages than currently exist.

We are witnessing dramatic changes to the form and method of delivery of vocational education. I am concerned about the way in which that form and that method of delivery actually impact on individual workers. I am concerned about the proliferation of private providers and the adequacy of existing measures, let alone measures proposed under this arrangement, to ensure that there is effective policing of the quality of training that is undertaken.

I have deep concerns about the loss of quality of training measures as a result of this government's changes to the vocational education system. It is a concern that not only I have; it is a concern that I believe is widely felt within industry. We are concerned about the levels of deskilling and the narrowing of training options for workers that are arising as a result of this government's actions, and which are now being replicated by various backward looking conservative state governments. We have seen in the states of Victoria and Queensland moves to remove declaration of trades and vocations and replace them with so-called accredited courses. We have seen the undermining of the apprenticeship system and a proliferation of narrow enterprise based apprenticeships, limitations on portability and, in my opinion, a widespread exploitation which arises from the growth in what I call cheap and nasty training packages.

What you will see is a government that is pushing growth without proper funding in regard to the vocational education system. I have a fear that, as a consequence of that increase in levels of activity by various providers without funding, there must be a reduction in the level of quality. I am concerned that the government is launching an attack upon the apprenticeship system. We have seen their attempt to remove apprenticeship designations from federal awards, even where you have employers such as the MTIA and the ACM in agreement. We have seen actions by the government before various courts in this country to remove those longstanding provisions in awards reached by agreement. This is part of a general approach by this government to promote individual contracts for apprentices and trainees. It is a much easier vehicle to force young workers in particular to accept lower wages and lower levels of training.

The Senate ought not regard this as just an academic exercise. It ought to be seen in the context of what workers have to put up with in terms of the deskilling which arises from these actions. Deskilling for workers means fewer job opportunities, not more. It means lower wages, not higher wages. It means lower standards of living. These are regulations which, in my mind, will open the door to these actions by unscrupulous employers—ruthless employers who have no real interest in the long-term viability of training within industry.

These regulations have significant implications for workers—mostly young workers—in regard to their career paths, their pay, and of course the portability of qualifications and the integrity of the Australian qualification framework. They allow for an inconsistent use of the qualification levels.

These regulations, in my view, are a device to provide for a more flexible interpretation of the various commitments that this government has already given to the Australian Democrats when the original debate occurred on the workplace relations regulations. They are commitments which we said at the time were totally inadequate and which are being demonstrated to be so by these regulations. They provide a vehicle to circumvent the national training award. They allow for variations in awards under the so-called disadvantage test and they will provide a vehicle for various employers who seek to use them to reduce trainee and apprenticeship wages.

These regulations should be opposed because the approving authority acts within guidelines which fail to prevent a number of quite serious problems. These guidelines are fundamentally flawed. There are a number of inadequacies which are highlighted by the fact that existing employees who are under awards get their full rate when training but under these arrangements they could have their pay reduced. A further inadequacy is that an apprenticeship could be retitled as a traineeship and there would be a subsequent reduction in wages as a result.

Further inadequacies are the fact that national training wage award traineeships could be renamed in order to provide so-called new flexible traineeships. That new designation is a device by which unscrupulous employers can use the determinations of these so-called approving authorities to seek variations to awards under the no disadvantage test—in so doing, the rates of pay of workers engaged in training are reduced. The regulations also have transitional arrangements in them which in themselves highlight the inadequacies of the government's approach. The transitional arrangements are so vague that we could end up seeing arrangements that fit either the old or the new models—whichever suits the employer. That is all very well if you have a good employer or an employer who is committed to long-term training in an industry, but that is sadly not the case all too often. Section 8 of these regulations says:

. . . The Australian vocational education and training system is currently undergoing a number of substantial reforms. These reforms may take some time to finalise at the national level and to be implemented by industry.
It continues at 8.1:

A training agreement may not be available at the time at which approval of a traineeship or apprenticeship for the purposes of the Act is sought from the approving authority. In these circumstances, it will be necessary for the approving authority to consider the traineeship or apprenticeship for approval under sections 170XC or 170XD of the Act without these agreements. In deciding whether to approve an apprenticeship or a traineeship and in making determinations for those which are approved the approving authority may take into account information such as the following about the training arrangements for the traineeship or apprenticeship:
This is quite clearly far too vague an arrangement, far too serious a matter to be left in the hands of approving authorities under these circumstances.

The whole truth of the matter is quite simple. What this government is seeking to do under these regulations is to get around section 170X of the Workplace Relations Act. This section excludes the approving authority from being able to make any determination under 170XC with regard to the national training wage traineeships. Under the Workplace Relations Act, if an AWA or a CA is entered into by a trainee then the award, for the purpose of the no disadvantage test, can be either, firstly, a national training award for the national training wage traineeship; or, secondly, if it is not a national training award traineeship, the junior wage rate in the parent award is adjusted where necessary by an approving authority determination of training hours.

The Commonwealth is trying to say under these measures that a traineeship that uses exactly the same materials, goes for the same period of time, has the same working hours and provides an identical qualification under the national training award traineeships could have a new designation as a so-called flexible traineeship and hence is no longer eligible for the rates of pay as set down in the Workplace Relations Act.

For many industries that will mean large pay cuts for individual workers. For example, a young person in the metal industry could have their pay cut from $170 a week to $104.40 a week. This is before any determination is made about hours spent in training. Under these regulations there are a whole series of measures which seem reasonable on the surface but, when you look at the detail, they could quite seriously disadvantage the wages and conditions of workers engaged in training or an apprenticeship.

If the approving authority makes such a determination, the young person will have their pay reduced even further than I have already indicated. So there is a double attack on wages and conditions under these regulations—an approach that can produce lower hourly rates of pay and a potential drop in the number of hours they actually get paid for. With most awards, the more time that is spent in training, the less money is actually paid.

There are other problems with the guidelines. The answer to those problems is not in having more approving authorities. I believe that the regulations fail to meet the criteria which have already been agreed to by the government and Australian Democrats at the time of the workplace relations debate. As I understand it, that agreement involved a proposed regulation which would `contain guidelines on who else may qualify as an approving authority. They would deal with issues such as necessary expertise, the need to avoid conflict of interest, the necessity for training courses to comply with national competency standards etc. They could also allow state training authorities to delegate their function as an approving authority to other bodies, but only if strict criteria are met.' These strict crieria are not being met.

These regulations are part of the government's attempt to decrease apprentices' pay and conditions and reduce the quality of training that they receive. In recent estimates hearings we heard of an increasing tendency for a proliferation of these so-called private providers, including industry training advisory bodies. It is clear that, under these regulations, they would automatically get approval, yet there quite clearly is a conflict of interest for an advisory body to act as an employing body. For the individual worker, that can mean nothing but trouble. These regulations need to be seen in the broader context of what is happening to the vocational education and training system in this country.

This government has reduced employer subsidies for taking on apprentices by some 40 per cent. There has been a sharp decline in apprenticeship numbers. This government's policies mean that apprenticeships are being replaced by short-term—often very short-term—traineeships. We have seen a narrowing of the training base and a deskilling of workers. We have seen the growth in apprenticeship commitments drop by 25 per cent in the last two years. This government is projecting a growth of some 12,000 new traineeships, compared to a growth of only 2,667 apprenticeships.

We are seeing a shift away from apprenticeships to traineeships, but we are not seeing adequate protection for workers under these new arrangements. We are seeing a move to short-term quick fix training, which increasingly is being encouraged by private providers. TAFE directors tell me that these matters are increasingly of concern in so far as they involve persons who will not necessarily have a commitment to the long-term interests of training in any particular industry.

This government is overseeing a period of great confusion, a period of great uncertainty. Many employers now believe that apprenticeships do not exist at all; that only traineeships are operating. There is a lack of promotion and an absence of any real commitment by this government to quality vocational education and training. We are seeing privatisation of public institutions and privatisation of our TAFE colleges. We are seeing massive job shedding in the public sector in that regard, which has, of course, impacted on the number of apprenticeships being offered by the public sector. All these things have combined to produce a culture which is, I think, highly negative for the advancement of training for young people in this country.

There is also a move by some agencies within government to use the training regime introduced by this government to exploit workers. One example was brought to my attention recently. A 50-year-old fully trained printer was placed in a printing industry traineeship. In his first five weeks in the traineeship he was working unsupervised and was not being paid for overtime. There was no training involved in his placement. He was, of course, being used as nothing more than cheap labour by the company concerned, rather than being provided with adequate training.

This government talks about devolution of these authorities to state governments, but we have to look at the records of those state governments. They have been sacking very large numbers of workers in the public sector and they are reducing their commitment to training. Some six per cent of training undertaken by the private sector is in apprenticeships; a figure considerably less than has traditionally been the case. The Victorian government has abolished declared trades. Allowances are now being made for the dismissal of apprentices despite various arrangements which normally protect apprentices from unfair dismissal.

We are seeing the removal of the right to continue in an apprenticeship upon the transmission of any particular business. We are seeing the removal of scrutiny by the state board of young people undertaking apprenticeships in various trades. We are seeing an open-ended probation period for apprentices. A general decline in the level of protection is now being experienced by apprentices and trainees. These regulations will do nothing more than increase the vulnerability of young workers. But it will not be just young workers who are affected; older workers who are obliged to undertake training programs—so-called traineeships which are, of course, nothing more than cheap labour schemes—will also be affected.

Most employers, from my dealings with them, have a long-term commitment to training and apprenticeships—most big employers, that is. The problem is that smaller employers often do not have that commitment. The fly-by-night operators, the unscrupulous operators, are undermining the commitment to training of the more scrupulous and those who actually are interested in the long-term future of their industry. This measure will only exacerbate the pressure upon the reasonable employers who are committed to ensuring there is adequate protection and quality of provision. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the motion moved by Senator Carr. He has moved:

speech.para: That the Workplace Relations Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 314 and made under the Workplace Relations Act 1996, be disallowed.

Senator Carr has presented one of his usual diatribes here today. We have had continuing slagging of the business sector and what the business sector might do; fly-by-night operators; unscrupulous people. This is the usual old union rhetoric that we hear when the Manager of Opposition Business in the Senate tries to denigrate what is happening out there in the workplace.

The reality of what is happening in the workplace is that, as we move into a very rapidly changing industrial structure, we need a much more flexible approach to training. What we have put forward here is a series of regulations, after careful consultation with a wide group of people, that very carefully set up this new system. There have been negotiations across parties. There have been negotiations with industry.

Senator Carr has to realise that we are moving into this new world. The old type of approach that we had previously, particularly the standard type of apprenticeship that might have run for four years, is just not appropriate anymore in the current industrial environment. That is why, when we brought in the new system, we called it a new apprenticeship system to reflect those changes.

It took the Labor Party a very long time to wake up to the need for changing the way in which we handle training in this country. That is shown, Senator Carr, by the absolutely dismal record of your government over 13 years in the apprenticeship area. You should hang your heads in shame that you, the Labor Party, the party that claims to represent the workers, did so little for people in basic training in the apprenticeship system.

One of the reasons why it failed, apart from the ineptitude of your government, was the very rapidly changing nature of industry and the globalisation of our economy. The way in which that led to less security in business meant that the old approach where you might require an employer to put someone on for about four years just was not going to work anymore. This government has come up with a much better and more carefully crafted approach, a much more flexible approach, so that you can get a range of different types of training systems that work that are more targeted to what is needed on the job front.

I know this goes against Labor's broad view, Senator Carr. I know it goes against your own inclinations on the way things should be structured. I know from your speeches in this place over many years that you like this big, centralised, top-down type system with a lot of central controls. Those days are now passed. That is not the appropriate way to run things. We have delegated this to a broader range of providers in a far more flexible approach to its control.

Regulation 30ZR states the criteria to be met to be declared an approving authority and says that the proposed authority must have experience and expertise in vocational education and training. The minister must be satisfied that the proposed authority will act fairly. Regulation 30ZS enables the delegation of approving authority functions by state or territory training authorities which are declared. I do not understand why Senator Carr actually opposes that. The explanatory statement of the regulations makes it clear that its purpose is to allow the powers and the functions of approving authorities to be more widely devolved and assist in making the vocational education and training system more responsive to the needs of business and industry. Why should there be any argument with that?

talk.start.para: —Because it doesn't protect workers; that's why. It doesn't protect the trainee or the apprenticeship.

—Senator Carr, you have come in here today and made a lot of assertions. You have said that businesses are dodgy, they are fly-by-night, they are unscru pulous, workers will not be protected and there will be a great drop in wages. Where is your evidence of any of this, Senator Carr? Where is the raw evidence? Today, you have provided us with no evidence at all on these matters. You have just come out with a whole lot of pejorative statements saying that our approach will not work. We do know, of course, that your approach—the one you had when you were in government—did not work at all.

speech.para: You have come up with claims that there will be massive changes which will lower the quality of training. Again, where is the evidence of that? You are criticising private providers. If we have a look at the way in which it was operating in the last few years under you, there were quite a lot of private providers. The whole system was moving to private providers. Are you saying that was wrong at that time? What is happening is just a normal evolution of that process.

talk.start.para: —Tell us about user choice.

—Where is the evidence of deskilling? Are you talking here about the possibility that, say, in some apprenticeships they might take a shorter time to do the initial apprenticeship? Is that the deskilling you are talking about?

speech.para: Let us take bricklayers as an example. There are certain core skills you need as a bricklayer, and probably about 95 per cent of the time that is all you do in bricklaying. On top of that, of course, there is some very fancy work that you can do in bricklaying—the way you do semicircles, the way you put in very special types of brickwork. It might take you the full apprenticeship to develop that but, initially, at the entry level, you do not need that. Would it not be far better to spend less time on some of those skills and then, by some post approach to the initial training, develop those skills further on?

That is the sort of flexibility that we feel we need in the workplace. That is not the flexibility that I assume you are advocating. What are you advocating, Senator Carr? We have not really heard. You have been very negative, very critical, about what the government is proposing, but what are you suggesting, Senator Carr? Are you suggesting that perhaps we go back to four-year apprenticeships? How did you go under that? Didn't you end up with 60,000? What a disgraceful record at the end of 13 years. Under our proposal, we are moving to 200,000 apprenticeships, traineeships. Under what we are proposing is a move that more reflects what is going on in the economy of this nation. So you stand up here with very little credibility, given what happened under the previous government.

We are making the vocational education and training system much more responsive to the needs of business and industry. The regulations that we formed, the ones that are here being considered today, have been formed after a wide range of consultation with all parties. Those consultations fulfilled and went beyond the strict requirement of the agreement that was made with the Australian Democrats on the passage of the Workplace Relations Bill. With this government's policy, apprenticeships and traineeships will be more attractive to business and industry, Senator Carr. Let me emphasise the reason: they are more flexible, they are often not as long and businesses are more likely to take people on.

These regulations are part of the government's effort to create more entry level training opportunity, particularly for young people. Senator Carr, it seems, and the Labor Party, which he represents, want to hinder that. These regulations should not be disallowed. Senator Carr said he is concerned about the approving authority. Again, I think this is part of his centralist approach. He is missing several very important points in terms of approving authorities.

There are now three approving authorities. They are already declared under the act's existing provisions, and these authorities are actively making determinations. Let me clear this up for Senator Carr. He has left the chamber and that is a pity, as I was just going to clear up this point for him. The approving authorities make determinations about the effect of training on work time and progressions through wage levels. Let me repeat that—and I hope Senator Carr is listening to this somewhere—they make determinations on the effect on work time and progressions through wage levels. When Senator Carr was standing there slagging what we were doing, and what he is proposing in disallowing the regulations, he was trying to claim that this was going to lead to a drop in wage levels, but these authorities do not set wages.

These regulations contain strict criteria that have to be met to be declared an approving authority. Proposed authorities must have experience and expertise in vocational education and training. The minister must be totally satisfied that the proposed authority will act fairly. These criteria will ensure that approving authorities are aboveboard, and this should relieve the concerns that Senator Carr raised earlier.

These safeguards show that the opposition is not correct in claiming that these regulations will dilute the quality of training received by apprentices and trainees. Approving authorities will only make determinations on apprenticeships and traineeships which sit within the national training framework and lead to nationally recognised qualifications. This government has ensured that these regulations will not result in the exploitation of apprentices or trainees. Why is the opposition pretending to be concerned about apprentices and trainees when the apprenticeship system collapsed totally under the ALP's 13 years of mismanagement in this area?

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance motion moved today by the opposition. We are well aware of the changing nature of not only the workplace but the education environment and, in particular, the training environment. We are very conscious of the need for flexibility, and indeed some reform, within that training environment. However, this does not mean that we are willing to accept a lack of quality or a reduction in quality in that environment, nor are we prepared to throw out accountability mechanisms or channels through which we can ensure there is quality accreditation, especially when it comes to providers of training. So we share the concerns articulated by Senator Carr on behalf of the opposition today in relation to accreditation and quality in the training environment. It is those concerns that motivate us to support the disallowance motion before us.

speech.para: I should also add that we are acutely aware of the need for greater education and training opportunities for people in the Australian community—in particular, for young Australians. We have expressed many times in this place our concern with both sides of the chamber but, in particular, with the current government, which has compounded the high levels of youth unemployment by scaling back funding for education and training opportunities for young Australians. We are acutely aware of the need for an injection of funds to ensure that young Australians, in particular, have access to skills development and the acquisition of knowledge. We all know—and certainly, Senator Tierney, this is a sentiment I got from your speech—that education, training and skills acquisition are the keys to a successful and competitive workplace.

I only have to draw the Senate's attention to the Dusseldorp Skills Forum report that was released on Friday to demonstrate that there is a lack of education, training and employment opportunities for young people in Australia today. I wish to place on record, for the second time today, my disappointment at the failure of the government and the opposition to respond in any meaningful detail to the Dusseldorp Skills Forum report. I think that report raises some devastating concerns for this government and for previous governments. So the Democrats are very concerned about the nature of the training environment.

We note that the Workplace Relations Act 1996 established a framework, if you like, for more flexible apprenticeships and traineeships. The act actually provides for individual Australian workplace agreements for apprenticeships and traineeships, allowing for part-time training or modification of other award provisions subject to the overall no disadvantage test. However, these agreements require that the actual apprenticeships or traineeships be approved by an approving authority as being within the national training framework and of course fair to the trainees involved. Under the act, the minister can declare as approving authorities state training authorities—for example, TAFE departments, industry training advisory boards or such other bodies that meet the requirements.

I should at this point acknowledge Senator Tierney's point that there was consultation in the lead-up to the formulation of the provisions in the act, but I must put on record that he was wrong when he claimed that the agreement organised between the government and the Democrats on this particular section of the act has been met and that the strict criteria have been fulfilled, because that has not happened. If that had happened, the Democrats may have been partial to support the government on this, but we will not support the government because we are very angry that the strict criteria that were laid down as part of those negotiations and consultations have not been met. So I place on the record very strongly the fact that Senator Tierney was wrong in his statement in the chamber earlier in relation to meeting the guidelines and the criteria developed between the Democrats and the government.

We made it clear in our 1996 agreement with the government that the regulations must contain clear guidelines on the types of bodies to become approving authorities, including the necessary expertise, the need to avoid conflicts of interests and the necessity for training courses to comply with national competency standards. The regulations presented by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Dr Kemp, fall short of these conditions simply through their use of such general terms. We know that this could allow the minister to designate many unqualified or perhaps biased organisations as training authorities, opening up the prospect of substandard training programs being approved with the wages of trainees and apprentices cut as a result.

The ACTU agrees and concurs with us on this point—that is, the strict criteria laid down by the Democrats has not been met. I quote from a letter from the ACTU Assistant Secretary, Tim Palace. He writes that the regula tions do not meet the strict criteria. The correspondence states:
The regulations fail to meet the criteria agreed with the Australian Democrats.
This is completely contrary to the assertions we have just had from Senator Tierney in this place. It goes on to read:
The agreement between the Commonwealth Government and the Australian Democrats provided that:

a) The Minister may declare as an approving authority a State or Territory Training authority, an Industry Training Advisory Body (ITAB) or any other body which meets the requirements set out in a Regulation (4.7 and 170x).

b) The regulation would contain guidelines on who may qualify as an approving authority based on strict criteria to avoid conflict of interest, ensure necessary expertise and ensure training complies with national competency standards etc (4.8).
c) The guidelines would be developed in conjunction with governments, employers and unions through the ANTA process (4.9).
d) There will also be guidelines concerning the way an approving authority is to carry out its functions (4.10).

The criteria have not been satisfied. For that reason, the Democrats today will be supporting the repeal of the regulation on training authorities. We are not ruling out a redrafted regulation. As I said in my speech during the second reading debate in this place on the Workplace Relations Bill in 1996:

We are of the firm view that training arrangements should not be approved unless they are in the best interests of trainees. It is their interests, not the interests of employers, that must be paramount. From that point of view, we oppose the suggestion that training arrangements in AWAs could be approved by people who are not competent to do so, by local employment councils synonymous with local chambers of commerce as I believe has been suggested by some. Training arrangements must be consistent with the national training framework and regional training standards as enforced by state training authorities, industry training bodies and other such bodies.

They were the comments made in the chamber at that time of the bill's passage. But the government has failed to date to establish the need for this particular regulation that has been presented by the minister—that is, the government has failed to show exactly what sort of additional approving authorities are needed. So far under the act the only bodies to be declared approving authorities have been the state TAFE authorities. Assuming that the industry training boards follow, it is a little difficult to see why additional bodies would be needed. I ask the minister perhaps when he comments on the disallowance motion before us to explain why we need additional bodies because I am starting to wonder why indeed we do.

The tendering out of employment services to private providers and the compulsion of young people to work for their meagre unemployment benefits through the work for the dole scheme highlights the need for close examination of this particular regulation. In this context, the quality of training must not be compromised and it is essential that there remains a clear and firm gatekeeper on the quality of training and, through that, the operation of the no disadvantage test on AWAs under the Workplace Relations Act.

In voting to disallow this regulation, the Democrats are saying to the government, to the minister, if you insist you can bring it back later, but bring it back when and if you have a clearer idea of exactly who the additional approving authorities will be and what criteria will be applied to ensure that such authorities will act in the best interests of trainees and apprentices.

I wish to turn very briefly to another example of this government's failure to ensure adequate opportunities, employment wise and training wise, for young people just to highlight another area where the government should be assisting traineeships and apprenticeships. Perhaps the minister would like to address this in his comments: the decision by the government to make massive cuts and changes to the CRAFT scheme, the Commonwealth rebate for apprentice full-time training scheme. I understand the government seeks to make a saving of $133 million by the changes and the cuts to this scheme.

In conjunction with the regulations we have before us, it really suggests that the government's agenda for training and training reform in this country is a sorry one indeed. I ask the minister whether or not this is simply a penny-pinching, revenue raising exercise on behalf of the government because I cannot see how they will be assisting young people or indeed their trainers or employers by making cuts to the CRAFT scheme. We know currently employers receive around $2,500 tax free if they take on new full-time apprentices under the CRAFT scheme. Yet the budget last year announced that this incentive will be made taxable with a further payment of $1,500 made available upon completion of the apprenticeship roughly three years later.

For an unincorporated small business, the effect of these measures is to reduce the commencement and progression incentives by around $1,200 after tax. Even after receiving the final payment a small business would be still around $440 worse off. Incorporated business will lose $900 after tax on the commencement and progression incentives with the difference only being made up with the final payment when the apprenticeship is completed.

So the result of these changes may be a substantial budget saving of around $133 million over four years but these changes inevitably make taking on apprentices less attractive for employers, particularly employers in small businesses. This is a particular concern given that the number of apprentices is estimated to have fallen dramatically in recent years from around $49,742 commencements in 1994-95 to $43,930 in 1995-96 to just $40,495 in 1996-97. So clearly now is not the time to be cutting apprenticeships, let alone incentives to employers to take on apprentices.

The Democrats remain committed to fostering an environment where perhaps the training environment can be more flexible but we will not do so at the expense of quality or at the expense of accountability and certainly when it comes to the regulation of and approval of those various industry and training approval authorities. We will be supporting the disallowance motion before the chamber today.

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr and Senator Stott Despoja have made quite convincing arguments as to why these workplace relations regulations should be disallowed. The other speaker so far has been Senator Tierney. In my view, what he had to say showed, again, why these regulations should be disallowed. He painted a very rosy picture but he based it on suppositions, or facts, if you like, which may or may not be accepted but which are not prescribed in these regulations. In other words, he painted a picture which may or may not be borne out in fact but which, in any event, is not provided for in these regulations. That is the problem with these regulations. As Senator Stott Despoja said, there may be a basis upon which a further set of regulations can be approved but certainly not these ones.

speech.para: I will explain that in a little more detail. These regulations are proposed to make effective part VIE of the Workplace Relations Act. Part VIA talks about the minimum entitlements of employees; part VIB talks about certified agreements; part VID talks about Australian workplace agreements and part VIE, which I shall refer to, talks about the no disadvantage test in respect of which these regulations are to operate.

Those parts deal with conditions and the remuneration which are to be received by employees employed by different people. These regulations talk about an approving authority. An approving authority has the function, as has been stated by Senator Carr, of putting into operation a plan whereby apprentices or apprentice-like employees can be remunerated. These approving authorities have considerable influence on what wages people will receive. That can be ascertained from section 170XC of the workplace relations legislation. Subsection 2 states:
For the purposes of subsection (1)—
that is, working out a proportion of the wages that a person is to lose by undertaking training—

the appropriate percentage of the benchmark rate is such percentage of that rate as is determined in writing by the approving authority having regard to the reduction in the productive time of an employee undertaking the approved traineeship due to time spent in training.

So the approving authority has to make a decision as to how much time is productive time when a person is in training. The employee cannot determine how much time is productive, nor can the employer. It is up to the approving authority, and it is up to the approving authority to ascertain whether a particular traineeship is a worthy one or not.

The approving authority has a very important part to play in the scheme of training. It is for that reason that the definition of approving authority in the act says that the approving authority means any person or unincorporated body that—
. . . is a state or territory training authority that exercises approval powers in relation to traineeships or apprenticeships—

and it says that if the state has a system whereby these approving authorities are set up, those approving authorities are worthy approving authorities for the purposes of the Commonwealth act, and that seems to be reasonable—
or is an Industry Training Advisory Body—
again that seems reasonable—
or meets the criteria prescribed for the purposes of this definition; and is declared in writing to be an approving authority for the purposes of this Part. . .

Given the seriousness of this matter, the criteria prescribed, one would have thought, should be very precise and defined. This part of the act is dedicated to the training of people and it is likely that it is going to be young people who will be affected and it is young people that need protection. If they have any disputes with a training authority and an approving authority they should be able to judge against very precise criteria whether or not the proposed authority is a proper one and is doing the work that it should do. It is important to find out what the criteria are. It is at that point that these regulations come into serious question because it is stated:
The prescribed criteria in relation to a person or unincorporated body (`the proposed authority' ) for the purposes of paragraph (c)—
that is the one I have been speaking about—
of the definition of `approving authority' in section 170X of the Act are that the Minister is satisfied that the proposed authority has:
. . . skills and experience of a high order in the field of vocational education and training . . .

What does that mean? Where are there any prescriptions about what skills and experiences of a high order involve? It is simply up to the minister to be satisfied of that. The second criterion states that the approving authority has:
. . . the capacity to act fairly in discharging the functions of an approving authority.

What is meant by `fairly' in this context? Fair to whom? Does it mean fair in terms of the economic soundness of the business? Does it mean fair in terms of whether or not the person is getting proper training? What does it mean by saying that all that the minister has to be satisfied of is the approving authority's capacity to act fairly? Why should the criterion not be that the minister is satisfied that the approving authority will act fairly. Any of us have a capacity to act fairly, but the real question is will we act fairly. To define an approving authority as one that has the capacity to act fairly seems to me to be too vague and too unsafe to allow through. The regulations go on to state:

For the purposes of paragraph 1(b), the Minister must consider whether the proposed authority, if declared to be an approving authority, will be likely to balance the interests of trainees or apprentices with those of employees in:
(a) approving traineeships and apprenticeships; and
(b) making determinations under section 170XC and 170XD of the Act.

Again, this is a standard which is hard to judge. I would ask the minister, who is very knowledgeable and skilled in this area, whether it would not be better to have a lot more precise criteria so that a young person could judge whether he or she is being properly treated.

The regulations, as they stand at the moment, are very vague. They are not the sort of regulations against which a person who might be interested can test whether or not the conditions have been met. How do you test whether an approving authority is likely to balance the interests of trainees or apprentices with those of the employers? What are the interests of trainees and apprentices? What are the interests of the employers?
The other problem with these regulations is delegation. The regulations go on to state:
An approving authority that is a State or Territory training authority may delegate its powers . . . and functions to:
(a) a State or Territory training authority of the same State . . .

It seems reasonable that if states have approved authorities then that, hopefully, should be some protection. Part (c) states in relation to an approving authority delegating its powers that it can delegate its powers to:
(c) a person or unincorporated body that, in the opinion of the approving authority, has:
(i) skills and experience of a high order in the field of vocational education and training; and
(ii) the capacity to act fairly in discharging the functions of an approved authority.

We can have an approving authority that can delegate its functions to another approving authority which it judges will act fairly. Again, what does that mean? The approving authority that is going to give the approval does not have to be satisfied that its delegate will act fairly but just that it has the capacity to do so. It is quite vague and quite at large and should not be passed in its present form.

There should be a set of regulations that prescribes in considerable detail what fairness means when talking about the interests of the employer and the interests of the apprentice. Does it mean that they should be given fair hours? Does it mean that they should be given proper training? What does proper training mean? Does it mean that you should have so many hours theoretical training, so many hours practical training or so many hours experience? The problem with these regulations is that they cannot be effectively tested by the people who might want to test them.

An employer might want to test a decision that is made by an approving authority. An employer might want to test the results of a decision of an approving authority. A young apprentice or a union that represents that young apprentice might want to do that. I ask the minister when he is replying to this matter to give us some idea of how a person who is unskilled in the law and might not be experienced in the way these things work can go to these regulations and work out whether they have been applied or not.

It is going to be very difficult for such a person to judge that because the way regulation 314 of 1997 is written it is so vague that it cannot be tested. It is bad to have regulations which cannot be tested. It is bad to have, in effect, a mission statement containing a set of aspirations rather than what regulations ought to be—that is, a prescription that people can use to measure whether or not they have been properly treated under the act or under the regulations themselves.

These regulations are very much like the preamble to an act. They are not in any way an exercise of what ought to be the power to make regulations—that is, to make specific and precise statements about what is going to happen under a particular act. Until they are tightened, until they are made more specific and until they are put in a state where an apprentice, a trainee or an employer can ascertain whether or not what is done under them is within the regulations or not, they should not be allowed to continue.

I congratulate Senator Carr in bringing forward this motion and congratulate the Democrats in picking up the lead that has been given in seeing that these regulations are in a satisfactory state. Indeed, any regulations put forward in this form would be unsatisfactory. I invite the Senate to reject them.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I thank senators for their contributions in this debate. It may be of some assistance to the Senate if we look to section 170X of the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act which deals with the no disadvantage test but more particularly the definition of an approving authority. The act states:

speech.para: approving authority means any person or unincorporated body that:
(a) is a State or Territory training authority that exercises approval powers in relation to traineeships or apprenticeships; or
(b) is an Industry Training Advisory Body; or
(c) meets the criteria prescribed for the purposes of this definition.

Within the act itself we have coverage of the state training authorities and the industry training advisory bodies. The main complaint seems to be in relation to the criteria prescribed for the purposes of this definition in so far as it relates to other bodies. What we have before us are regulations which are made pursuant to this very section.
Regulation 30ZR deals with the criteria that the minister has to have regard to when looking at an approving authority. That criterion, which was touched on by Senator Cooney, states:
. . . that the Minister has to be satisfied that the proposed authority—
which of course will make determinations about the structured training that someone needs to do in relation to a traineeship or apprenticeship—
has:
(a) skills and experience of a high order in the field of vocational education and training.

In the first instance, there is a requirement of satisfaction which is of a high degree. Not only that, but the minister also has to be satisfied that this body has a capacity to act fairly in discharging the functions of an approving authority.
Senator Cooney touched on what it means to act fairly. If you read on, you see that, for the purposes of this subparagraph which deals with acting fairly, subregulation (2) says:
. . . the Minister must consider whether the proposed authority, if declared to be an approving authority, will be likely to balance the interests of trainees or apprentices with those of employers.

That is a weighty consideration indeed. As far as discretions go, I would submit that this criterion is definitive because it requires the minister to address his or her mind to the fact of balance, balancing the interests of trainees or apprentices with those of employers. That is what then leads the minister to conclude whether this body would have the capacity to act fairly. We need to remember that state and territory training authorities have already been provided for in the act.

During the debate, Senator Stott Despoja queried why we should have the delegation power contained in the second regulation, 30ZS. Senator Stott Despoja misunderstood the reason for that delegation. It is essential for the state training authorities to have the ability to delegate. Senator Stott Despoja mentioned the question of TAFEs. TAFEs are not state training authorities. It may well be desirable that a TAFE might be necessarily categorised as such, but in order to achieve that status it would need the state training authority to have the power of delegation.

If TAFEs were to be included, as Senator Stott Despoja was alluding to, you would have to have this power of delegation for state training authorities. It is already the case that in Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia there are existing authorities which have been approved. In relation to other states where the state training authority wants to delegate, it is essential that they have the power to do so under this regulation.

With respect to the no disadvantage test, that is one which is applied in a compendious manner in part 6E of the act. It is translated in a more definitive way into these regulations. In fact, I think Senator Carr said that there was a danger that trainees or apprentices could suffer a reduction in wages by these approving authorities making determinations which would have the effect of reducing wages.

The government has announced its minimum training wage top up scheme. That is a scheme which will guarantee a training wage for people involved as trainees or apprentices, and I can give you the figures. For a 16-year-old, it is $134 per week; for a 17-year-old, it is $165 per week; and for an 18-year-old or over, it is $206. Any training above AQF 3 or higher is $231 a week. That is the national training wage. If, by inadvertence, a wage is reduced to below that, then it will be topped up to that minimum training wage level. So there you have the safety net, as it were, in a wage sense.

The other point raised by Senator Carr was that there might be some dilution of training, that there might be a deleterious effect on the training levels. It is part of this whole structure that an approving authority can only operate within the national training framework; that is, the state, Commonwealth and territory governments have come to agree on a national training framework, which applies across Australia. Contained in that is the Australian recognition framework, which I will come to shortly. That in itself has standards within which the approving authorities have to act.

The other point which was raised by Senator Carr was the portability of skills. The portability of skills is ensured by the Australian recognition framework, which puts in place the very aspect of national recognition of training; that is, you can qualify in one part of the country and be recognised in another. That is most important and is something which is not affected in any deleterious sense by these regulations.

In relation to the question of the Dusseldorp report which was referred to by Senator Stott Despoja, that was mentioned in the context of scaling back funding. I think the point which Senator Stott Despoja was making was that the Commonwealth government had scaled back funding and that the Dusseldorp report was in some way critical of the government's approach in this regard.

I remind the Senate that the Dusseldorp report related to the years 1985 to 1996, 10 years of which were under the previous Labor government, most of them under the member for Brand, Mr Kim Beazley, who was then the minister for employment and training. What the Dusseldorp report said was that young people between the ages of 15 and 19 had not progressed during that period. There had been a decline in apprenticeships, there had been a fall in retention rates—in fact, from 1992 to 1996 there had been a slip from 77 per cent to 71 per cent—and there had been, overall, a poor state of affairs indeed for young people in education and training. This is a conclusion by an independent report dealing with a period where 10 years out of 11 were under the previous Labor government.

I remind Senator Stott Despoja that this government has committed $187 million over four years for vocational education and training in schools. This is an essential starting point for vocational training for young people. What we are looking at is not just leaving it until the young person leaves school and then look at training them; we are looking at picking them up during the school system and funding programs which will pick up these young people who need to build a bridge from school into vocational training. In fact, what we are looking at are school based apprenticeships and traineeships, which are very much a thing for the future.

The Commonwealth has funding there for that. This is more than what the Labor government spent in its previous term in office which spanned some 13 years. I remind both the opposition and Senator Stott Despoja of that. But it does not stop there.

When you look back to June last year, the figure for apprentices and trainees, which would largely be younger people, was up 11 per cent from 1996, and that is pointing towards the government and its good policies. It is a positive step forward that this government has taken in relation to young apprentices and trainees. In fact, we will be introducing from 1 May new apprenticeship centres which are a one stop shop, streamlined application of how you go about becoming a trainee or apprentice. It does not only help the young person or older person who wants to go into training; it also helps those employers who, up until now, have thought the system too rigid and too hidebound in red tape.

The Commonwealth will also be allocating some $265 million in the 1997-98 financial year which will be devoted to the creation of more than 100,000 apprenticeships. Indigenous trainees for the financial year 1996-97 figured some 5,000, which compares greatly to 817 indigenous trainees in the financial year of 1994-95, the last complete year under the previous Labor rule.

When people say that there is a cutback in funding, they really are barking up the wrong tree in relation to this government. When they cite the Dusseldorp report as being in some way critical of the present government, it relates to a period in which for 10 years this government was not the government of the day.

Getting back to these regulations, these regulations provide safeguards in the exercise of ministerial discretion. They provide for delegation for the state training authorities, which is necessary if this is to operate smoothly around the country for those states who wish to delegate. It is a situation where the no disadvantage test has been translated from the act itself to apply to these approving authorities. For those who say, `Why should you have this flexibility?', I say that the whole regime of this new training approach is to have flexibility.

Senator Stott Despoja conceded in her address to the Senate that we are embarking on a new age of training—investing for the future and investing in our young people—which will take us into the next millennium. We need to be more flexible and we need to adapt to the times. That requires a training regime which is flexible and responsive to the needs of industry and the community. Therefore, we need the sort of flexibility where a ministerial discretion can be applied, but applied in a strict sense and with strict criteria.

The situation I pointed to at the outset—and that brings me back to that very first point—is that, if a state training authority were to delegate to a TAFE, it would need the power to do so under that second regulation 30ZS, because TAFEs are not by their nature state training authorities and do not come within the definition of section 170X of the act.

These regulations provide the security. We have a national training wage which provides a safety net—and I have mentioned the figures. These regulations provide the flexibility which is needed in the new training regime and, most importantly, these regulations translate the no disadvantage test into effect.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Carr's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Senator Brown by a letter dated 23 March 1998 has raised a matter of privilege under standing order 81 and asked that I give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee. The matter he raises is the alleged failure of Senator Parer to register and declare relevant interests in accordance with the resolutions of the Senate relating to senator's interests of 17 March 1994.

speech.para: Resolution four of the Senate's privileges resolutions require me to have regard to certain criteria in determining whether a motion should have precedence. Those criteria are designed to ensure that only sufficiently serious matters are referred to the Privileges Committee. Those criteria, however, are, in effect, pre-empted by the resolutions relating to senator's interests which include a provision that a senator who knowingly fails to register interests correctly in accordance with the resolution shall be guilty of a serious contempt of the Senate and shall be dealt with by the Senate accordingly, but the question whether any senator has committed such a serious contempt shall first be referred to the Privileges Committee for inquiry and report and may not be considered by any other committee.

The Senate having declared by that resolution that knowingly failing to register interests is a serious contempt, such a matter meets the criteria I am required to consider. The resolution relating to the declaration of interests does not contain a similar declaration that a failure to declare interests is a serious contempt, but it would be open to the Senate to treat such a failure to declare interest as with any other order of the Senate. I, therefore, give precedence to a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee.

If the reference is made, it will be then for the Privileges Committee to inquire and determine whether Senator Parer has knowingly failed to register or declare relevant interests. It is not for me to make such a determination at this time. I table the letter from Senator Brown. Senator Brown may now give a notice of motion in accordance with standing order 81.
