debateinfo.title: ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION REGULATIONS (REPEAL)

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Energy Research and Development Corporation Regulations (Repeal), as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 6 and made under the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989 , be disallowed.

I will speak very briefly to this. I realise that we could take half an hour or so, but I certainly won't. I believe that it really speaks for itself. The Energy Research and Development Corporation was set up to manage the federal government's direct investment in energy innovation and research in energy supply and use. The way this works is that it invests in energy projects right from concept through to commercialisation, focusing on traditional energy supply, alternative and renewable energy sources and systems, and sustainable energy use. It covers a range of things, including gas and liquid fuels, electricity generation, distribution and application of energy use in Australian industry, manufacturing, transport, the built environment, appliances, processing and agriculture—in other words, the full gamut.

The ERDC selects projects and then funds them to meet these priorities. Therefore, it supplies support to the private research sector. It is a big injector of funds in research and development—indeed, the major injector of funds—and was about ensuring that Australia had a leg-up in the new technology field, that we actually got into the sunrise industries and really made a contribution to the future of energy trends and use.

It has in its short time developed a very good reputation, a good name in the industry and research institutions, and it was helping to create a lot of jobs, not just jobs directly in the specific research areas but, as processes and procedures came on stream and as products were developed, further jobs down the line. As an Australian it was very good to see the Australian stamp on much of this marketed technology.

This highly successful organisation was to find its funding cut in the first Liberal budget, and its funding has since been abolished. It is Senator Parer who is moving this regulation to abolish the corporation itself, and this is what is before the Senate at the moment.

In the annual report of the Energy Research and Development Corporation, the chair and executive of BHP said that the decision for the abolition of the Energy Research and Development Corporation was unexpected. It created major problems and was inconsistent with indications of future support that even this government had given at the time of the election and also when it initially came into office. One can question the motives, and one can go on doing that, but I will not go into all that today. Whatever the motives, they have got rid of a premier organisation. This is very puzzling in light of the government's much trumpeted potential budget surplus that it is going to have this year. While to many it is obviously a huge amount of money, in terms of research and development we are, after all, talking about only $12½ million.

We are moving this motion today to disallow the regulation that actually abolishes the organisation in the hope that we can at least hang on to that. We will then take up the cudgels of asking, arguing and pushing for the government to actually fund it again. We have had approaches from a number of sectors about this organisation, and we have yet to find anyone who does not speak very highly of it. We believe that if the organisation is still at least in existence, although wound down, we would have a better chance of winding it up again than we would have if we abolish it altogether.

We have a problem in particular with an undertaking that was given that those organisations that were actually undertaking work at the moment would be maintained. It seems that this has not happened. Contractors who had spent quite large sums on the capital technology required for their projects were under the impression, and indeed were given an undertaking, that projects would continue. They have apparently had the rug pulled out from under them.

Whilst the initial annual report of the ERDC last year had a statement from the chair promising commitments would be met, that report was withdrawn and later a statement was made in the House on 4 March indicating that contracts would be renegotiated with a view to savings. I would be very interested to hear from the minister exactly where that is up to now.

Another very positive thing about this organisation is that for every dollar spent by the ERDC, $3 was committed by industry and others. So it provided a multiplier effect as far as the amount of money actually going into research and development is concerned.

I will close by saying that there are a large number of projects that should be developed and continued. The ERDC was only part way into what it could have achieved, and it has been stopped well short of reaching its full potential. Surely the investment already made and the contributions that are very well recognised as to what it has already done are very worth while. What it could have done, I believe, was very worth while, and I look forward to support in the chamber for at least maintaining the organisation.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the opposition, I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Lees to disallow the regulation. In doing so, we point out that this is not the first time, unfortunately, this government has acted in a crass way towards the research and development community in this country.

speech.para: I remember when I was a minister in the industry area we were roundly set upon by the likes of Senator Parer, now the minister, saying that we were not doing enough to promote Australian industry. Yet when the new government took office, it went almost with deliberate glee about reducing Australia's research and development capacity.

The most infamous decision was to reduce the 150 per cent tax deduction to 125 per cent. That was roundly condemned by every sensible industry person and every sensible person involved in R&D in this country. People who condemned it were not normally noted as being supporters of the Labor Party by any means. We had industry organisations and well-known and public supporters of the election of the coalition government expressing their strong disquiet at a number of these decisions of the government to reduce the funding.

I can almost anticipate now what Senator Parer is going to stand up and say. It will be, `Ah, yes, but we had inherited a budget deficit when we were elected; this was a horrifying figure.' The figure which will be used will be $10 billion. I have to point out that, in relation to the 1996 figure, when we came into office in 1983, John Howard, as Treasurer, left us with an equivalent deficit of $23 billion at today's figures. So I do not think there is any comparison. But that was used as an excuse to cut the expenditure in the industry portfolio for research and development in various forms.

I have to say that I suspect Senator Parer, who has an industry background, was conscripted to this cause of slashing and burning in industry and R&D, because I think he has some understanding of the need to have R&D and to have the appropriate structures for Australian industry in place. But I also suspect that Senator Parer was outvoted by the Treasury and the finance ministers under the guise of reducing the deficit—that this was a terrible deficit and had to be tackled immediately, even though subsequent adjustments and estimations by Treasury have often proved to be wrong and, in this case, have proved wrong again, about the size of the deficit and about the fact that we are going to end up within a year of a surplus greater because of growth in the economy, as we have already pointed out.

But I think Senator Parer was probably disappointed that his view and knowledge of industry was overwhelmed by the Treasury view. Treasury have always had it in particularly for those programs in the industry portfolios that promote the development of Australian industry. I think the phrase that Treasury uses is, `This is industry welfare.' I do not think I am talking out of turn when I say that, when we were in government, I remember going to a briefing by Treasury for Labor ministers discussing industry policy, and the Treasury brief was to describe the proposals we were putting forward to develop Australian industry as `industry welfare'.

In the lead-up to the first budget in 1996, guess what term Treasurer Costello was using. We had to cut these expenditures because they were `industry welfare'. Governments come and go, it seems, and Treasurers come and go, but the Treasury view is always the same. They hated giving the 150 per cent when that was agreed to by the Labor government in the mid-1980s to boost R&D. They despised it and fought against it. In every budget in the rest of the Labor term of office Treasury fought at every opportunity to remove the 150 per cent tax concession. They always fought to remove various programs to assist in the development of Australian industry.

Ironically, when a new government comes in they get the chance to trick and bamboozle the new Treasurer—in this case, the famous Mr Costello, who often prides himself on being a tough person—and to say, `These are the programs that should be cut.' And of course they were. In the long term it is against Australia's economic interest to have R&D cut, because the only way we will deal with our foreign debt—in both the private and the public sector but particularly in the private sector—and our current account trade deficit is to boost the value of Australia's exports. The only way to do that is to prove the value adding of them by having decent R&D looking at ways in which those products can be improved in their value.

We always argued in government that the reason we supported investment programs, R&D programs—whether they were direct funding in a properly transparent process of application and grants or whether they were a tax deduction like the 150 per cent—was that these would lead to an increase in value in Australia's economy by increasing our exports and increasing jobs. That is not a view that the Australian Treasury accept in any way. They have a flat-earth view that, if you just get the deficit down, get into surplus, get low interest rates and low inflation, everything else will look after itself. That may happen in an economy the size of America with 260 million people, an economy running into many trillions of dollars. With an economy of our size—18 million people on a large continent—you need discrete, proper, balanced government intervention and support for Australian industry.

So today we have an outcome of the mad decisions of this government from when it came in in 1996 and from the follow-up budget in 1997 in putting in a regulation to abolish the Energy Research and Development Corporation of Australia. It is extraordinary that the minister who prides himself on coming from the coal industry, the mineral industry of Australia, has to come in here to defend the winding up of the Energy Research and Development Corporation. One would have thought that this would be something this minister would go to the wall to fight to keep. But we have heard nothing from the minister, despite the fact that his own industry and the broader Australian industry do not want these sorts of programs wound up.

In the budget of last year we saw just how mean spirited this government is. The government abolished the Energy Research Development Corporation, slashed a further $11 million from the national energy efficiency program on top of $3 million cuts in the 1996 budget. All of these decisions are clear breaches of the 1996 federal coalition promises. The then shadow minister, Senator Parer, personally promised that the coalition would:
maintain current support for the Energy Research and Development Corporation and continue the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development.
That was in the coalition resources and energy policy document at page 14.

talk.start.para: —I wasn't the shadow minister.

—You weren't the shadow minister? I apologise, Senator Parer. But in view of your interest in the mining industry I suspect you would have supported that being in the coalition document for the last election.

speech.para: What do we have instead of maintaining that support for the R&D? Senator Parer and the government have abolished it. And last year they reduced the R&D tax concession to 125 per cent. On 16 August 1996, Senator Parer claimed in a press release that:
the government recognises the important role renewable energy plays in protecting the environment, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and laying the foundation for long-term, sustainable development.
The press release goes on to say:

Government support for renewable energy in Australia includes the funding for the Energy Research and Development Corporation and the Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy and Related Greenhouse Gas Reduction Technologies.

Those are the words of Senator Parer on 16 August 1996. That is almost what the Democrats would say, Senator. I was going to give you a big tick. This is a quote that would not be amiss in a Democrat document about renewable energy, which is an issue they campaign quite strongly on.

In August 1996 we had this glowing statement from the minister in favour of the Energy Research and Development Corporation and funding for the CRCs in the same area—the cooperative research centres—and yet a year later this minister has to come in here with an enormous amount of egg on his face and move the regulation that the Energy Research and Development Corporation of which he had spoken so glowingly should be abolished. It is a Greg Louganis job as a diver, Senator Parer: a double somersault with backflips all over the place from your position in August 1996 to your position in August 1997 and again to your position here in the Senate in March 1998 in putting up this proposal to abolish the Energy Research and Development Corporation. We believe that in the long run this government's policies, if they are allowed to continue, will damage Australia's industrial development capacity, its R&D capacity and its technological development capacity in a most grievous way.

This government still has not come to grips with having a decent industry and science research and development policy. As a former minister in the area of industry and science, I agree with Senator Parer that it is not possible to satisfy everybody in the science community and the research and development community. There is always a long list of people demanding access to government funding for various research programs. But this government has not made any attempt to meet those demands; it has cut them all back and ignored them. What I find rather strange, if not sad, is that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is on the record as saying on a number of occasions, `We should not concentrate on doing value adding to our minerals in Australia. We should concentrate on just sending them overseas as raw tonnage.' We all know that, no matter how much is dug out of the ground in raw tonnage, the full value is never realised. That is why we have a consistent current account deficit, this year running to $20 billion plus.

The countries that run the biggest trade surpluses in the world are those that have good value adding, manufacturing industries, et cetera. Unless we get some of that in Australia, we will always be on the wrong side of the ledger with our current account deficit. This is something this government is incapable of coming to terms with in its industry policy. Here we see the saddest example of all. I would have thought that, at the very least, Minister, if you were not going to fund the Energy Research and Development Corporation, you would have quietly crept off in the night, left the shell there and given it no money. I would not have thought you would have the gall to come into this place and move a regulation to abolish it when, only 18 months ago, in 1996, you were quoting what a wonderful organisation the Energy Research and Development Corporation was.

I find that really odd. I think it is a sad commentary on this government's industry policy. Therefore, the opposition has no hesitation in supporting the motion of the Democrats to disallow the winding up of this organisation. I think the government should be heartily condemned by the Senate for this cheeky regulation here today. I conclude on this point to Senator Parer: we look forward to the coming election campaign on the issues of industry policy, science policy and research and development.

talk.start.para: —You haven't got any.

—You are just wiping them out, Senator Parer. You do not have an industry policy. You have no idea. The only ideas on industry you have taken up are the ones that we have announced. You took our policies for the manufacturing industry and the car industry. You took the policy that we announced for clothing and textiles. Those are the ones that we announced, and then you belatedly came to the table and said, `This is what we're going to adopt.' They are the industry policies that you have adopted. You closed down so many of our policies and then you discovered, `Gee, they weren't too bad.' You are now reintroducing some of them in a rebadged way, but only at a lot lower level.

speech.para: We look forward to the next election campaign—whenever it is in the next few months—to chase this government all over Australia and down every burrow to expose them as having no industry policy. This regulation today is a living example of their having no policy.

talk.start.para: —The regulation before parliament envisages the ERDC ceasing operations on 1 July 1998, with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy taking over responsibility for managing the remaining ERDC portfolio from 1 July 1998.

speech.para: Since its establishment, the ERDC has played a significant role in advancing energy supply and using technologies. The government considered ERDC had established a good foundation for industry to take on a greater role in funding its research in conjunction with other government assistance.

The government's decision to wind up the ERDC was taken in the context of severe fiscal difficulties left to the government by the previous Labor administration. Because of the need for tight fiscal discipline, the government has had to make the difficult decision to cease funding new investments in energy R&D through the ERDC. The government also needed to ensure the most efficient delivery for support of energy research and development, and it was clear that energy research and development was being supported by a number of programs between which there was significant duplication of effort. In addition to ERDC, the Commonwealth government was funding energy R&D through the CSIRO, which had an energy R&D budget of $44.4 million in 1995-96, programs such as the cooperative research centre program, the R&D start program and the renewable energy industry program.

Following the winding up of the ERDC, there will be substantial support for energy research and development through government programs and market based incentives. The R&D start program, which was announced in the August 1996 budget, provides funding for R&D, including energy R&D. The program provides a mixture of support measures, including grants and loans for R&D in small and medium enterprises. Total expenditure on the R&D start program over the next four years will be $739 million. The R&D start program is a potential source of government support for energy R&D projects. The program has already granted funding for energy R&D projects, including in new and renewable energy. As senators will be aware, this is within the portfolio of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism.

Specific support for energy R&D is also provided by the government through the Australian Cooperative Research Centre's program, which includes the Australian Cooperative Research Centre for Renewable Energy, ACRE. ACRE has a Commonwealth contribution from the CRC program of over $10 million over seven years and focuses on a number of sources of renewable energy, including solar, thermal, photovoltaics and wind. There has been further incentive for industry to undertake R&D from the 125 per cent tax deduction and the existence of significantly more robust and competitive energy markets in Australia flowing from gas and electricity market reforms accelerated under this government.

A process that had lost momentum under Labor, energy market reform, has created the impetus for innovative products and services and facilitated wider use of low emission energy supplies, such as co-generation, gas-fired generators and renewable energy systems. As a result of Australia's electricity grids being opened up to the private generators, the opportunity for generators using renewable energy technologies has increased. This in turn provides a major incentive for energy research and development. Significant developments have included a supply of over 50 megawatts to the grid using sugar cane waste, or bagasse, the establishment of over 70 megawatts of power plant capacity using gas in municipal landfills and over 125 megawatts of new capacity from small hydro plants.

New support for energy research and development has been announced as part of the government's response to the greenhouse issue. In November 1997, as part of the $180 million five-year program, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) announced a major new package of measures to encourage innovation in the renewable energy sector. These include $21 million for a renewable energy innovation investment fund on a two for one funding basis with industry and $30 million of concessional loans and grants for development and commercialisation of strategically important renewable energy technologies. This represents a huge increase on the $4.8 million over four years spent by Labor on the renewable energy industry program. There is $10 million for a showcase fund—and I am sure you will support this, Senator—to support leading edge renewable energy projects in areas such as tidal power, solar thermal power and photovoltaics.

Other measures in this package will stimulate support for energy research and development. These include programs for the mandatory targets for uptake of renewable energy and power supplies; efficiency standards for power generation; an environmental strategy for the automotive industry; industry efficiency benchmarking and best practice; energy performance codes and standards for commercial buildings, domestic appliances and industrial equipment; and energy efficiency improvements in Commonwealth operation.

There has been much bleating by the Australian Democrats alleging that the wind-up of the ERDC will impair Australia's efforts in alternative or renewable energy research developments. These claims, which were repeated in Senator Lees's media release of 22 March 1998, serve only to highlight the Democrats' failure to comprehend energy policy issues and to acknowledge the extensive support for renewable energy put in place by the Howard government. Far from decreasing support for renewable energy, initiatives taken by the Howard government provide a boost for investments specifically targeted at renewable energy.

While the ERDC provided funds for all energy research, the program announced by the Prime Minister has a deliberate renewable energy focus. As a result of these measures, the level of support provided by the government for renewables is considerably greater than that provided by any previous government. As part of the wind-up of ERDC, the government will not fund any new investments by ERDC but will meet existing commitments. I think Senator Lees talked about these negotiations in her speech. These negotiations are not compulsory but, where it is to the advantage of both sides, they will occur. In the absence of those, the commitments will be fulfilled.

The opposition to this motion is really a futile piece of grandstanding which will do nothing to promote its claimed objective of supporting alternative energy R&D. All that the Democrats will achieve, presumably with the support of Labor, is the maintenance of a minimal ERDC board without funding for new projects and no role whatsoever, the effective role residing mainly with the Australian greenhouse office and agencies within the industry, science and tourism portfolio.

talk.start.para: —I totally support Senator Lees's motion. I do so for the reasons she gave, and I want to reiterate those in my way. Firstly, we have here the $71 million that was allocated over five years to ERDC, which has a prodigious record for stimulating research and development, particularly in the fields of alternative energy, and drawing in many millions more from business and industry in that pursuit being denied. Under Minister Parer, $87 million is specifically allocated over the same period for research and development, into what? Into wind energy? Into solar energy? Into energy alternatives which people concerned about greenhouse gases and so on might be concerned about? No, none of those. The $87 million is going for research and development into the coal industry.

speech.para: So there we have it—$71 million being taken from the ERDC and $87 million going into the coal industry. If there is ever a benighted misdirection of policy, that is it. How could this minister, this government, under the glare of public interest in energy alternatives with the globe warming up, with the enormous fear there is from the threats of global warming, be proceeding in the reverse direction to that which the Australian people would expect? It is unconscionable.

At some stage down the line, the government needs to be stopped in its tracks and made to think about what it is doing. I know that Senator Parer has a favourable eye on the coal industry. One has only to read the newspapers to know that. But there is much more at stake here than the interests of the coal industry. There is the direction this nation is going as a potential leader in research and development in the renewable energy field—solar power, wind power and energy efficiency, not least.

So Senator Lees is quite right to make this move to try to put a shot across the bows of this delinquent policy direction that Senator Parer and the government are taking. We have in this country some of the best scientific and research and development expertise—not the least of whom are in universities—in energy renewables anywhere in the world. Some have already been forced to go overseas with their inventions. More are feeling the squeeze.

In the meantime, we have Senator Parer and the government allocating $87 million to the coal industry—and, by the way, another $24 million to other fossil fuel research and development, making a total of $111 million—but they cannot fund the $71 million the ERDC was getting because Senator Parer says we are facing tight fiscal conditions. What bunkum! What nonsense! As I said, what a delinquent policy direction.

One only has to look at the government's policy reversal on the diesel fuel rebate—which involves over $1 billion a year, most of it handed to the mining corporations—to see how much easier it would be for the government to reverse its decision on the abolition of the ERDC and the emphasis that needs to be given to research and development in energy renewables. I am aghast and so are many people in the business field, I can tell you, at the direction this government has gone. It is not only a loss now for small business and research and development in this country; it is cutting across the interests of this country as a whole because energy renewables are a sunrise industry. They are one of the identified king-hit industries of the next century. The whole world is going to be looking for the expertise and the investment coming out of this research and development.

Instead of fostering that, instead of looking ahead, what Senator Parer is doing is looking backwards. He is looking at the now. He is no doubt, because of his long association with the coal industry, being impressed by the arguments and the understanding he has there, while ignoring a more balanced, progressive and forward looking understanding which comes from the recognition that this country can lead the world, reap profits and create hundreds of thousands of jobs—but if only government are prepared to get behind the industries that are making such terrific advances for Australia in this field.

Instead of getting behind the industry, Senator Parer is simply getting behind. He is going backwards. It is a delinquent policy. The ERDC, instead of being abolished, should be enhanced. Senator Lees is to be congratulated for this attempt to stop the government in its tracks and make it think again in the interests of this country of ours.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Lees's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Order! There being no further consideration of government business, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to discuss the Prime Minister's recent visit to the Northern Territory. John Howard commenced his visit with a very successful day in Darwin on 26 February. He visited the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. He viewed the East Arm Port Development, which will be a vital part of the Darwin to Alice Springs railway link, with Chief Minister, Shane Stone, and the Northern Territory transport minister, Barry Coulter. He also attended a dinner for 350, hosted by my colleague the federal member for the Northern Territory, the Hon. Nick Dondas.

speech.para: He then had the honour on Friday, 27 February of visiting several communities in Arnhem Land at the invitation of Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, the Chairman of ATSIC. The Prime Minister visited Galiwinku, Marthakal and Dhambala on Elcho Island and Nhulunbuy and Yirrkala on the Gove Peninsula. At Galiwinku the Prime Minister was briefed on a $1.8 million joint army/ATSIC project. This project involves the building of 10 new homes plus the upgrading of existing power and water supplies. It is expected the project will prove as successful as a similar one at Bulla near the township of Timber Creek where army personnel are a very good example of the different sections of the Australian community establishing personal connections with Aborigines and working on a deeper understanding of each other's culture.

The Prime Minister was similarly accorded the opportunity of enhancing his own understanding of Aboriginal culture at Dhambala on Elcho Island where he, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator John Herron, my colleague Nick Dondas and I were given the very great honour and privilege of participating in a secret men's ceremony with Garrawurra elders. I understand the honour and accept the trust placed in us by the Garrawurra men and realise that it is a privilege extended to very few white Australians. Let me say that the importance and significance of the ceremony and its symbolism and insignia used was not unlike that of a freemason's lodge. The Prime Minister was obviously moved by the ceremony and shortly after said:

I deeply appreciated the honour that was paid to me and I certainly gained from that ceremony an understanding of how much that ritual and that culture and those thousands of years of practice and history mean to the indigenous community.

After visiting another public function with hundreds of elders, women and children from Galiwinku, the Prime Minister and our party left for the town of Nhulunbuy where his first duties were at the Miwatj Aboriginal health centre. It was here that the Prime Minister announced a $4.8 million innovative health package to help combat trachoma in Aboriginal communities.

After addressing a business leaders luncheon celebrating the 25th anniversary of the Nabalco bauxite mine, the Prime Minister visited the home of his host, Gatjil Djerrkura, at the lovely community of Yirrkala. A traditional ceremony of welcome by members of the Djapu clan in full ceremonial dress saw the Prime Minister escorted to the Yirrkala arts centre. This was a spectacular and impressive display particularly by many spear wielding men, women and children singing and dancing in a moving ceremony.

At the Yirrkala arts centre details of sacred Aboriginal paintings were explained to the Prime Minister and he was presented with a special bark painting of cultural significance. We also on that occasion met with senior traditional leaders for another private meeting on important cultural values.

The visit by Mr Howard highlighted for me the fact that there are so many aspects to Aboriginal life and culture that are not given the important publicity they deserve. Some life or death issues, particularly when talking about the maintenance of a culture, deserve much more consideration. A common thread running through the discussions on the day was the need for Aboriginal culture to cross generations, in fact for traditional culture to be handed down from generation to generation and not lost forever.

We must ask the question: are the views of Aboriginal people in the far-flung settlements of outback Australia being listened to, canvassed and voiced by some of the radical Aboriginal leaders that we have in Australia today? I am not convinced that they are. Too many Aboriginal spokesmen in the non-ceremonial or traditional areas have lost the focus and lost the plot.

In my electorate, the Northern Territory, a vast area of 1.3 million square kilometres, with Aborigines making up 25 per cent of the population—a higher percentage than in any other state or territory—there are hundreds of Aboriginal communities, all with many diverse needs and aspirations. As I have travelled the Territory during the past 25 years of my political career, I have heard many concerned voices, particularly by Aboriginal people, on those isolated communities that follow a number of common themes—themes and issues that are not getting much recognition or voice from the Aboriginal leaders living on the east coast of Australia who seem preoccupied with the concept of land ownership and a continuation of welfare support and government dependency.

There is very little mention being made of the wonderful art and the ancient living Aboriginal culture that is practised still in so many Aboriginal communities and the need to ensure its protection and survival. I seriously ask: where is the discussion, the action and the acceptance from southern Aboriginal leaders of the many other aspects of Aboriginal life and culture that are so important and many other issues that need to be canvassed at a national level, other than native title or land rights?

Where is the recognition that for many Aboriginal people land rights and native title are not major issues? They know their site and their place in the world with far more spirituality than most of us. A unique and splendid way of life is on the brink of extinction. The major issue for many people in remote communities is the loss of culture, the loss of their traditional way of life, the loss for many of their very being, their sense of identity. The preservation of what is unique about themselves and their lives is what is important to so many of my constituents.

The preservation of the hundreds of Aboriginal languages and dialects spoken around Australia is a first step in helping to maintain this identity. Action is being taken in the Northern Territory schools to ensure the survival of Aboriginal languages, but why is there not more of an outcry elsewhere? Surely language is vital to a culture's survival. Our focus on literacy must allow Aborigines to communicate in the two societies in which they must live.

Aboriginal health and nutrition is deplorable. Why not promote the use of bush tucker before the knowledge is lost and a healthy food source lost with it? Again, in the Territory this has been recognised, but why are Aboriginal leaders in other states not promoting it much more strongly and loudly? Closely related to the skills used to find bush tucker are the skills gained over thousands of years, generations living and learning in the most trying conditions to acquire the unique hunting and tracking abilities needed for survival itself. Action must be taken before these skills are lost totally.

The importance of ceremony to Aboriginal people as a part of their culture must also be recognised and steps taken to ensure that its continuation is enshrined. Aboriginal art is finally getting the recognition it deserves but there are still many challenges to be met in this area, particularly in recognising copyright and preservation issues.

The Reverend Djiniyini Gondara spoke recently to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and made several very important points relating to the native title process and the cultural issues I have described that must be addressed. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the recent speech by Djiniyini Gondara.
Leave granted.
Address by Rev. DHINIYINI GONDARA to the RECONCILIATION COUNCIL. 11/3/98
Thank you for your welcome Mr. Chairman.

Today we are talking about the Commonwealth Constitution and looking at how it might be changed in the future. I think the best way I can add to this debate is by speaking about my traditional Law—the Madayin of the Yolnu people of North East Arnhem Land. Then we might be able to see how this can help our discussion.

Before I start, it would be good to say that Yolnu are only one group of Aboriginal Clan/Nations within the Northern Territory. However my knowledge of other Aboriginal Clan/Nations across the country is that we each have very similar foundational principles of law.
To me there are three main elements in any good law and this is how it is with Yolnu traditional law.
These three elements come from the djalkiri or the foundational source of our law. These three main elements that must be found in all law are;
1. The law must create Magaya . That is, the law must create a state of peace, harmony, and tranquillity, with true justice for all the citizens.
2. The law must be Dhapirrk That is, the law must be perfectly consistent with all the different levels of law from the source down to the lowest acts of law.

3. The third element of good law is that it must be Wana Lupthun . That is the law must be assented to by the citizens in a ceremony that shows that they are all under the discipline, responsibility and protection of the law.

No law and no constitution would be recognised as real law without these foundational principles being included. This is how it is with Yolnu traditional law—the Madayin. I have learnt this from my traditional law.
I have just used the term—Madayin. Madayin is the terns Yolnu use to talk about our law. So you can understand what I am talking about here, I would like to look at what Madayin means.

But before I do, I would like to point out what Justice Blackburn said in 1971. In his judgement and summing up of the Gove Land Rights case he said that he "could see that a `rule of lava and not a `rule of marl' operated in Yolnu society."
The Madayin is based on a rule of law not because Justice Blackburn said so but because it is and we have known that for thousands of years.
Lets look at the Madayin, our traditional law.
Madayin is the name for a complete system of law for the Yolnu (Aboriginal people) of North East Arnhem Land.
It embodies the rights of the owners of the law, or citizens, (rom-watanu walal ) who have the rights and responsibilities for this particular embodiment of law.

This Madayin includes: all the peoples' law (rom ), the instruments and objects that encode and symbolise the law (Madayin girri ), oral dictates, names and song cycles and the holy, restricted places (dhuyu nungat wana ) that are used in the maintenance, education and development of law.

This law covers the ownership of land and waters, the resources on or within these lands and waters, it regulates and controls; production and trade, the moral, social and religious law including laws for the conservation of, and the farming of, fauna, flora and aquatic life.
The Yolnu of Worth East Arnhem Land believe that if they live out their life according to the Madayin it is a right and civilised way to live.
The Madayin creates the state of magaya. Magaya is a state of peace, free from hostilities, true justice for all.
Some of the political structures which are established by the Madayin are:

Bapurru —is the name given to the paternal estate owning clan/nation—who have ownership of the surface of the land and waters of the estate. This includes all the resources on the land and in the water.
Yirralka —the estate of the Bapurru, which is divided into distinct areas for natural forming.

Ringitj— an alliance of clan/nations with a common constitutional base (as seen in the Dhulmu-mulka bathi ), song cycles, common army, and common practice of law- this alliance has the sub-surface ownership for their estates of land and water. See ARDS Information Paper No. 5
The political representatives of the clan/nation are called Dalkarra and Djirrikay .

Narra is a chamber of law and jurisdiction where the leaders are called together by the clap sticks. Secrecy provisions apply creating a type of parliamentary privilege so that the only information to leave the chamber is the publicly viewed objects that encode the law (like the sacred Dilly Bag). The citizens are outside the chamber or the ceremonial place and the law is taken to them.

Wana Lupthun— after a draft law is discussed and by consensus is agreed to by the representatives in the chamber, the objects (like the Dhulmu-mulka bathi— sacred dilly bag) are brought out for the citizens to assent to. In this Ceremony the objects representing the law are held by the political leader of that clan/nation and he, together with all the people of that clan, go under the water to indicate that they are under the discipline, responsibility and protection of the law. No one is above the law!

The principle-"separation of powers "—is embodied within the concept of Yothu/Yindi. For Yolnu this is much more than the name of a rock band. The members of the government are from one clan/nation and are called Yindi. The public servants, including the police and officers of the court are from separate clan/nations and are called Yothu .

If someone breaks our traditional law, we have a process to deal with this at law. Some people who do not know our traditional law have called this "payback ", but we know it as bayarra . To Yolnu it means to be reconciled at law.
These sanctions are carried out by our ceremonial leaders, who are the authorised officers, according to the dictates of the law.
Bayarra, reconciliation at law, then occurs.
"Payback", or an action of revenge without a due legal process, is against Yolnu traditional law.

So you can see, just as Justice Blackburn did, that Yolnu live under a rule of law not a rule of man. We have had this law, our Madayin , since time immemorial and each generation has tried to maintain the three foundational elements that I mentioned at the start of any speech. It is these three elements that all of us must seek to maintain within our Australian Constitution.
Mr. Chairman I thank you for the opportunity to have addressed this Convention.

para.inline: Key Terms In Understanding Yolnu Traditional Law

speech.para: Yolnu 1. The indigenous people of North East Arnhem Land.
2. Person. human being.
Balanda non-Aboriginal persons of European origin.

Madayin the name for the traditional laws of the Yolnu people of North East Arnhem Land. Madayin is a complete system of law encompassing all aspects of law found in the Westminster system of government.
Djalkiri foundational source of the law

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. The Prime Minister, Senator Herron, Nick Dondas and I were certainly accorded a unique and special experience with Aboriginal elders on 27 February and hopefully, one day soon, we will be able to reciprocate by inviting them on a visit to Canberra and Parliament House.

—Tonight I rise to speak about conservation groups. As the Senate will be aware, there are many conservation groups of all shapes and sizes in Australia. Tonight I wish to pay tribute to the work that they do and the way in which they make our community and our way of life much more valuable. I pay tribute to the individuals in those conservation groups for the considerable work they do. The reason for my comments tonight is that, in the context of this year's budget, I would like the government to recognise and acknowledge the enormity of the debt that we owe to conservation groups in this country.

speech.para: Some $1.7 million has been the amount provided for a number of years to be divided amongst a very large number of groups. Since the Howard government came to power they have added more groups to that list, but, unfortunately, that money has remained at the same level. Unfortunately, too, they have used that money as a stick to beat certain groups like the North Queensland Conservation Council, the Cairns and Far North Environment Centre, the Australian Conservation Foundation, the Environmental Defenders Offices and Friends of the Earth. All of these groups had their funding cut last year, no doubt as punishment for the kind of brutal honesty which did not fit with the government's notion of a relaxed and comfortable society.

I want tonight to compare their meagre funding with that of the mining industry which received $117 million in 1996-97. Next year it will receive around $90 million. Over five years the mining industry is expected to receive $333 million from government. We compare this with just $8 million going to conservation groups. Obviously, there is a very significant difference between those two amounts of money.

The government will argue that it gets back lots of revenue from helping the mining industry, but its economic model will only include the positive side of that ledger. It will not talk about the massive cost of mining leaving behind polluted land. It will not talk about job losses from mine closures and technology changes. It will not talk about polluted waterways and the cost of having that land locked up.

Let us not forget about the enormous sums of money involved in tourism to our unique and precious areas. I remind the Senate that if it was not for conservation groups the Great Barrier Reef would probably by now be polluted by oil drilling and, no doubt, be overfished. Kakadu would be mined. Fraser Island would have had its magnificent forest logged and its stunning sand dunes destroyed by mineral sand operations. South-west Tasmania would have suffered the fates of mining and logging and been flooded by an unnecessary dam.

The wet tropics rainforests, home to so much biodiversity and the only developed world tropical rainforests, would no doubt also be gone. We would have seen Daintree forests replaced by suburb blocks and cement. I could go on, but the point I want to make is that these areas are now recognised as unique in the world and they bring in billions of dollars of tourism. Their intrinsic worth is countless and their spiritual worth to who we are as a nation, is extraordinary.

These places, along with hundreds of national parks and reserve areas, exist because of the selfless and solid work of community environment groups. It is not just the natural environment that these groups protect. They are our security against land, air and water pollution. They research and identify potential problems with chemicals or toxic overload. They intelligently scrutinise decisions made by those who have a profit-only motive and by governments who help those organisations.

They point out the fast-tracking and inadequate decision making. They draw attention to the other side of the science. They find the loopholes and help inform the rest of the community. They negotiate to make projects and developers take softer paths on the environment, very often saving those developers money in the process. When enough is enough they stand firm on their principles and, in so doing, annoy governments because they cannot be bought and sometimes they just will not budge. They work nights, days and weekends and very often do this whilst holding down full-time jobs and having families. They still donate their time doing what they believe and what we know and recognise is the right thing to do.

Many governments and developers do not understand this sort of behaviour. Governments think that if they ignore them they will go away. They tend to shoot the messenger for what they have to say. But, of course, they are not going to go away. They are the voice of reason and I think they are very important to the future of this country.

In the government's rush to help out their big business mates—and it does not seem to matter whether it is a Liberal or Labor government in this respect—I want to warn the Senate tonight that community groups like the one I came from some years back and the ones I know, will not give up. They will simply become more insistent. I urge the government to take the opportunity this year to fund them in a respectful manner, to recognise the work they do and to recognise what they contribute to the quality of life for all Australians.

They are the ones who stand up for two very important groups who have no voice and yet should be listened to carefully before decisions are made. I refer to all of the species that we are privileged to share our fragile piece of planet with and all of those children who are not yet born but who will have to suffer the impact of the decisions which we make every day in their lives.

talk.start.para: —This evening I rise to address what I and the coalition regard as a very important issue for all people, particularly in greater western Sydney—that is, the issue of small business reform. My New South Wales coali tion colleagues are undoubtedly aware of the significance of the greater western Sydney area in terms of its population growth and its growth in industry—in particular, in the manufacturing, building and construction, transport and storage, engineering and retail sectors. I am pleased to have the opportunity on almost a daily basis to work closely with my colleagues the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) and the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly) in this part of Sydney, listening to and working with business.

speech.para: On a national level, though, small business confidence has firmed over the last three months to February of this year and is now at its highest level since the post-election peak of May 1996. The informative February 1998 Yellow Pages Small Business Index shows that business confidence is up this quarter in manufacturing, building construction and building services, with the transport and storage sector—essential parts of the western Sydney business community—seeing a boost in confidence of eight per cent—from 45 to 62 per cent since the November quarter.

The index tellingly goes on to say that, with the exception of the election induced euphoria in the May 1996 survey, small business's assessment of the economy is now at its strongest level since February 1995. Proprietors in all states and territories are strongly positive about the current state of the economy. In New South Wales, our small business proprietors have the strongest perception of economic growth and a strong sales and profit growth. The coalition's approach to small business reform is undeniably paying off right across the nation. This means that important areas such as Sydney's greater west have the opportunity to expand in business and to contribute in a far greater capacity to the nation's economy.

The greater west generates 20 per cent of the New South Wales work force and some 24 per cent of the New South Wales economy. The coalition acknowledges the contribution of the businesses of greater western Sydney and has fostered an open and accessible approach to receiving feedback from business proprietors at a grassroots level by providing opportunities to discuss the issues confronting businesses through seminars, forums and the like.

Just last Thursday I had the pleasure of chairing such a forum in Penrith. The event was organised by my colleague the member for Lindsay, Jackie Kelly, and the President of the Penrith and Districts Chamber of Commerce, Mr Ian Palmer. About 70 representatives of small business in both western Sydney and the Blue Mountains area were able to attend. A range of guest speakers was able to join us including my New South Wales state parliamentary colleagues the Hon. John Hannaford MLC, the opposition's spokesperson on small business in New South Wales; the Hon. Chris Hartcher MP, the opposition's spokesperson on industrial relations; the Hon. Mike Gallacher MLC, who spoke on workers compensation; and particularly my federal colleague the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, the Hon. Alan Cadman, the member for Mitchell.

The seminar's great success was a reflection of the work of one of the many strong organisations that stand behind small business in the greater western Sydney area—that is, in this case, the Penrith and Districts Chamber of Commerce. As with all of the various chambers of commerce in our area, they are actively involved in ensuring that small business is aware of the changes that are occurring at the federal level and the options that are available to all small business as a result of the reforms that this government has introduced.

But the chambers do not only represent small businesses as a cohesive whole; they work with the community. They work through the local print media to ensure that people are informed about the issues that are confronting their own small businesses and the options that are available to them. One of the most interesting things to come out of the seminar, and very timely, might I say, in relation to today's activities in the chamber, was strong, unanimous and steadfast support for the government's proposed changes to unfair dismissal laws in the Workplace Relations Act, which was today rejected in the chamber.

The opposition's job-destroying unfair dismissal laws left over from their period in government have been amended since the coalition's victory in March 1996. But the message from small business is that more changes are necessary for the continued viability of their sector. It is a message that has gone unheeded by those on the other side. It is clear that the rejection of the government's amendments means a more difficult road ahead for any prospects of expansion for this vital sector.

What those on the other side must now do is stand accountable before their small business communities in their electorates across the nation and explain to all proprietors the obscure agenda behind their rejection of these amendments. The proposed changes set out to achieve one thing: very simply, to provide a better future for small business in this country, to provide certainty for small business.

The opposition and the Democrats have made a conscious decision to place obstacles in the way of those things and in the way of Australia's economic prosperity. The coalition by contrast sees its role as providing business with the opportunity to move forward. The reforms that we have introduced and the commitment we have shown to small business is evident in the mood of the small business proprietors I spoke to in Penrith last week and all across western Sydney in fact. It is comforting to them at least to know that as yet we are only part way through our program of reform. There is more to be done and they, the people on the ground, the people in the workplaces, support our aims.

I find it difficult to understand the obstructionist activities of those opposite when the call from the electorate for reform in this area is absolutely unequivocal. What the government has done is to provide a positive atmosphere for business to get on with the job. For example, interest rates are at their lowest in 30 years. This is an atmosphere that is conducive to confidence in investment for a small business that looks to a bigger and brighter future. If businesses are to make decisions to expand, they need to know where they are going and where they are going to be in a couple of years time. The low interest rates and low inflation achievements of this government provide small business with the stability and certainty they need to make their decisions for the future.

I was particularly encouraged at the small business seminar in Penrith to also witness the support for the coalition's proposed tax reform. There was a clear message—that compliance costs to do with taxation and administration are hurting Australian business. The coalition's tax reform will create world's best practice to ensure that Australian business is competitive not only within our region but also with business around the world. It is ridiculous that Australian businesses can spend more hours per week working out complicated compliance issues than in any other country in our region. This government is about creating a framework for a successful and competitive future for small business. The representatives of the Penrith and Districts Chamber of Commerce present last week gave me and my colleagues a clear indication that they consider the coalition is in fact on track to achieve these aims.

But tax reform and the need for changes to the unfair dismissal laws were only two of the major issues raised at the seminar. A number of the government's other reforms in areas such as access for small business to the Commonwealth banking ombudsman, cutting tax on savings, cutting fringe benefits and capital gains tax, cutting red tape and giving retail tenants a fair go were all equally applauded.

It would be remiss of me not to point out that overwhelmingly the most important achievement of this government for small business was our efforts to repay Labor's debt. We have in fact come a long way under the guidance of the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) and the federal Treasurer (Mr Costello). We acknowledge that there are areas that still need to be addressed. We are working towards rectifying the unacceptable situation that was left over from 13 years of Labor Party administration.

If we want to ensure a successful small business community not only nationwide but also for greater western Sydney we have to listen. That is what we are all about—identifying the problem areas at a grassroots level and responding to them. There are encouraging signs of growth. People in Sydney's west are expanding whether in industries like real estate, construction or retail. Let us hope that the actions of those opposite today will not affect that trend.

I would on this occasion also like to bring to the attention of the Senate not only the success of the government's reforms in greater western Sydney but also acknowledge the strong organisational support that exists for business in the area. In addition to the chambers of commerce, I am also in contact with the Greater Western Sydney Business Connection, known to those familiar with it in the west as `The Connection'. Both the member for Parramatta, Mr Cameron, and I work with The Connection to take the message of western Sydney businesses to the government. It was established over 10 years ago in 1985 to promote the Parramatta CBD—which, after all, is the geographical heart of Sydney—and to enhance its business potential. After a decade of doing that, The Connection's focus is now directed across greater western Sydney. That wider focus has seen an expansion in business development opportunities which The Connection has championed since its inception. And growing out of the organisational structure of The Connection came the birth of the Asia Business Connection.

Western Sydney is a strong region for business. It is a rewarding job to bring back to this place words of encouragement and support for the framework that is being built from the coalition's small business policies—policies which go a long way to ensuring that business is not held back in western Sydney, but that it is in a strong position to move forward to the next millennium with sound business confidence.
